    When the ruler (heart) is clear, the subordinates (organs) are at peace. By nurturing life in this way, one will enjoy longevity and will not face danger in the world. If the ruler is unclear, the twelve officials (organs) are endangered, blocking the pathways and causing great harm to the body; thus, nurturing life in this way leads to catastrophe. If the heart is not clear, then the twelve officials will be unsettled. When the spirit is disordered, it causes blood and channels to coagulate, blocking the pathways. When the channels are obstructed, the body suffers greatly, leading to a calamity.[15p]

    　　　　　宣明五气论

    　　五劳所伤：久视伤血，久卧伤气，久坐伤肉，久立伤骨，久行伤筋，是谓五劳所伤。　　【注　上古之民，形劳而不倦。久视损神，故伤血。久卧则气不行，故伤气。脾喜运动，故久坐伤肉。久立则伤腰肾膝胫，故伤骨。行走罢极则伤筋。是五劳而伤五脏所主之血气筋骨也。】
    　　　　灵枢经

    　　　　　本神篇

    　　天之在我者德也，地之在我者气也，德流气薄而生者也。故生之来谓之精，两精相搏谓之神，随神往来者谓之魂，并精而出入者谓之魄。所以任物者谓之心，心有所忆谓之意，意之所存谓之志，因志而存变谓之思，因思而远慕谓之虑，因虑而处物谓之智。故智者之养生也，必顺四时而适寒暑，和喜怒而安居处，节阴阳而调刚柔，如是则邪僻不至，长生久视。　　 【注　故智者顺承天地之性，而得养生之道也。】[16p]

    Exposition on the Theory of the Five Qi

    The injuries caused by the five labors are: prolonged viewing injures the blood, prolonged lying injures the qi, prolonged sitting injures the flesh, prolonged standing injures the bones, and prolonged walking injures the tendons. These are the injuries caused by the five labors.

    [Note: In ancient times, people labored without fatigue. Prolonged viewing depletes the spirit, thus injuring the blood. Prolonged lying causes the qi to stagnate, hence injuring the qi. The spleen benefits from movement, so prolonged sitting injures the flesh. Prolonged standing injures the waist, kidneys, and knees, thus injuring the bones. Exhausting one’s walking injures the tendons. Thus, these five labors injure the blood, qi, tendons, and bones governed by the five organs.]

    Spiritual Pivot

    On the Mind and Spirit

    What exists within me from heaven is virtue; what exists within me from earth is qi. Virtue flows thinly to give rise to life. Therefore, the essence of life is called essence; the interaction of two essences is called spirit; what follows the spirit is called soul; the essence that enters and exits together is called po. Hence, the steward of things is called heart; when the heart remembers, it is called intent; what intent holds is called will; based on will, changes are stored, referred to as thought; arising from thought, distant longings are considered as concerns; and pertaining to concerns, interaction with things is termed wisdom. Thus, in the maintenance of life by the wise, one must follow the four seasons and adapt to cold and heat; harmonize joy and anger, and stay peacefully settled; moderate yin and yang to balance hardness and softness; if done so, then evil and deviance will not approach, leading to long life and prolonged vision.

    [Note: Therefore, the wise follow and embody the nature of heaven and earth to attain the way of nurturing life.][16p]

    　　　　　五味篇

    　　五味入于口也，各有所走，各有所病。酸走筋，多食之，令人癃。咸走血，多食之，令人渴。辛走气，多食之，令人洞心。苦走骨，多食之，令人变呕。甘走肉，多食之，令人悗心。　　 【注　心主血，肾主骨。苦乃火味，咸乃水味。苦走骨而咸走血者，阴阳水火之交济也。肺主气，故辛走气。】
    　　　　　本脏篇

    　　血和则经脉流行，营覆阴阳，筋骨劲强，关节清利矣。卫气和则分肉解利，皮肤调柔，腠理致密矣。志意和则精神专直，魂魄不散，悔怒不起，五脏不受邪矣。寒温和则六腑化谷，风痹不作，经脉通利，肢节得安矣。　　【注　血气神志和调，则五脏不受邪而形体得安。】[17p]

    Chapter on the Five Tastes

    The five tastes that enter the mouth each have their pathways and their respective ailments. Sour penetrates the tendons; excessive consumption leads to urinary issues. Salty penetrates the blood; excessive consumption causes thirst. Spicy penetrates the qi; excessive consumption unsettles the heart. Bitter penetrates the bones; excessive consumption induces vomiting. Sweet penetrates the flesh; excessive consumption harms the heart.

    Note: The heart governs blood, and the kidneys govern bones. Bitter is a fire taste, while salty is a water taste. The interplay of bitter affecting bones and salty affecting blood reflects the balance of yin and yang, water and fire. The lungs govern qi, hence spicy affects qi.

    Chapter on the Organs

    When blood is harmonious, the meridians flow smoothly, nourishing both yin and yang, strengthening tendons and bones, and clearing the joints. When the guardian qi is harmonious, it aids in meat division and eliminates blockages, making the skin supple and the pores tight. When the mind and will are harmonious, the spirit remains focused, the soul and essence do not scatter, remorse and anger do not arise, and the five organs are protected from evils. When cold and warmth are balanced, the six bowels process food properly, wind and pain do not occur, the meridians are unobstructed, and the limbs find comfort.

    Note: When blood, qi, and spirit are in harmony, the five organs are safeguarded from evils, and the body remains at peace.[17p]

    　　　　　百病始生篇

    　　喜怒不节则伤脏，脏伤则病起于阴也。清湿袭虚则病起于下，风雨袭虚则病起于上。　　 【注　按本经云：风寒伤形，忧恐忿怒伤气。气伤脏，乃病脏，寒伤形，乃病形；风伤筋脉，筋脉乃应。此形气外内之相应也。】
    　　　　　九宫八风篇

    　　风从其所居之乡来为实风，主生长养万物。从其冲后来为虚风，伤人者也，主杀主害者，谨候虚风而避之。故圣人日避虚邪之道，如避矢石然，邪弗能害，此之谓也。　　 【注　实风者，春之东风，夏之南风，秋之西风，冬之北风，春夏交之东南风，秋冬交之西北风，此四时之正气，故主生长养万物。从其冲后来者，如冬至从西南二方而来，春分从西北二方而来，是为虚乡不正之风，主伤人而杀害万物。故圣人日避虚邪之道，如避矢石。日避者，太乙出游之一日也。】[18p]

    The Treatise on the Origin of Diseases

    Excessive joy and anger damage the organs; when the organs are harmed, ailments arise from within. When dampness invades the weak, illnesses develop in the lower body; when wind and rain attack the weak, ailments manifest in the upper body.
    (Note: According to this text, wind and cold harm the body, while worry, fear, anger, and joy disturb the spirit. When the spirit is harmed, it affects the organs, leading to illness; cold harms the body, hence illnesses related to the body arise; wind injures the tendons, responding to such injury. This reflects the interaction between the internal and external aspects of body and spirit.)

    The Treatise on Nine Palaces and Eight Winds

    Winds that come from their native regions are termed true winds and are responsible for nourishing all living things. Winds that arrive from conflict zones are called false winds, which harm individuals, bringing death and destruction; one must be careful to avoid these false winds. Thus, the sage advises avoiding malicious forces as one would dodge arrows and stones, ensuring one is not harmed by them.
    (Note: True winds include the east wind of spring, the south wind of summer, the west wind of autumn, and the north wind of winter, as well as the southeast wind at the transition of spring and summer and the northwest wind at the transition of autumn and winter; these are the vital energies of the four seasons, responsible for nurturing all. In contrast, winds that come from conflict zones, such as southwest winds in winter or northwest winds during spring equinox, signify wrongly adjusted winds that harm individuals and destroy life. Hence, the sage advises avoiding such malevolent forces as one would dodge arrows and stones.)[18p]

    　　　　金匮要略 【汉　张机】

    　　　　　饮食禁忌

    　　凡饮食滋味，以养于生。食之有妨，反能为害。自非服药炼液，焉能不饮食乎？切见时人不闲调摄，疾灾竞起，若不因食而生，苟全其生，须知切忌者矣。所食之味，有与病相宜，有与身为害者。若得宜则益体，害则成疾，以此致危，例皆难疗。凡煮药饮汁以解毒者，虽云救急，不可热饮。诸毒病，得热更甚，宜冷服之。　　肝病禁辛，心病禁咸，脾病禁酸，肺病禁苦，肾病禁甘。春不食肝，夏不食心，秋不食肺，冬不食肾，四季不食脾。春不食肝者，为肝气王，脾气败，若食肝则又补肝。脾气败，尤甚不可救。又肝王之时，不可以死气入肝，恐扰魂也。若非王时即虚，以肝补之佳。余脏准此。[19p]

    Jinkui Yaolue [Han Dynasty, Zhang Ji]

    Dietary Restrictions

    In all matters of diet and flavor, the aim is to nourish life. If food is detrimental, it can cause harm. Unless one is taking medicinal elixirs, how can one avoid food? It is evident that people nowadays neglect regulation and care, leading to an increase in diseases and disasters; if one does not get ill from food, then to preserve life, one must be aware of what to avoid. The flavors of food may either be beneficial or harmful to the body. If suitable, they enhance health; if harmful, they cause illness, leading to serious dangers that are often difficult to treat. For all medicinal decoctions aimed at detoxification, although they are said to be for urgent relief, they should not be consumed hot. In cases of poisoning, consuming them hot exacerbates the condition, so they should be taken cold.

    For liver diseases, pungent flavors should be avoided; for heart conditions, salty flavors; for spleen issues, sour flavors; for lung diseases, bitter flavors; and for kidney ailments, sweet flavors. In spring, do not eat liver; in summer, do not eat heart; in autumn, do not eat lungs; and in winter, do not eat kidneys; and throughout the four seasons, do not eat spleen. In spring, avoiding liver is crucial because the liver is dominant, and if spleen energy is weakened, consuming liver would further support it. Weak spleen energy is especially difficult to remedy. Furthermore, during the dominant time of the liver, one should not introduce dead energy into the liver, for that may disturb the spirit. If it is not the dominant season, then supplementation of the liver is favorable. The same principle applies to other organs.[19p]

    　　　　中藏经 【汉　华佗】

    　　　　　调摄阴阳

    　　天者阳之宗，地者阴之属。阳者生之本，阴者死之基。天地之间，阴阳辅佐者，人也。得其阳者生，得其阴者死。阳中之阳为高真，阴中之阴为幽鬼。故锺于阳者长，锺于阴者短。多热者阳之主，多寒者阴之根。阳务其上，阴务其下。阳行也速，阴行也缓。阳之体轻，阴之体重。阴阳平则天地和而人气宁，阴阳逆则天地否而人气厥。故天地得其阳而炎炽，得其阴而寒凛。阳始于子前，末于午后；阴始于午后，末于子前。[20p]

    Zhong Cang Jing (The Book of the Central Repository) by Hua Tuo, Han Dynasty

    Balancing Yin and Yang

    Heaven is the source of Yang, and Earth belongs to Yin. Yang is the root of life, while Yin is the foundation of death. Between Heaven and Earth, humans assist in the balancing of Yin and Yang. Those who nurture Yang thrive, while those who cultivate Yin perish. The highest essence of Yang is the supreme truth, and the deepest aspect of Yin is the mysterious spirit. Therefore, those aligned with Yang live long, while those aligned with Yin have shorter lives. Excessive heat signifies the dominance of Yang, and excessive cold indicates the foundation of Yin. Yang acts from above, and Yin operates from below. The movement of Yang is swift, while the movement of Yin is slow. Yang's essence is light, and Yin's essence is heavy. When Yin and Yang are balanced, Heaven and Earth harmonize, leading to tranquility in human energy. When Yin and Yang are out of balance, Heaven and Earth are disrupted, resulting in human energy stagnation. Hence, when Heaven obtains Yang, it burns brightly; when Earth acquires Yin, it becomes cold. Yang begins in the early hours and ends after noon; Yin commences after noon and concludes in the early hours.[20p]

    阴阳盛衰，各在其时，更始更末，无有休息。人能从之，亦智也。《金匮》曰：秋首养阳，春首养阴。阳勿外闭，阴勿外侵。火出于木，水生于金，水火通济，上下相寻。人能循此，永不湮沉，此之谓也。呜呼！凡愚岂知是理？举止失宜，自致其罹。外以风寒暑湿，内以饥饱劳役，摧残正体，消亡正神，缚绊其身，死生告陈。死生至理，阴阳中明。阴气下而不上曰断络，阳气上而不下曰绝经。阴中之邪曰浊，阳中之邪曰清。火来坎户，水到离扃。阴阳相应，方乃和平。[21p]

    The rise and fall of yin and yang occur in their respective times, continually changing without rest. A person who can follow this is indeed wise. The "Essentials of the Golden Coffer" says: In autumn, nourish yang; in spring, nourish yin. Do not close off yang from the outside, and do not let yin invade from the outside. Fire arises from wood, and water is born from metal; water and fire communicate and connect, each seeking the other above and below. If a person can follow this, they will never fade away—this is what is meant. Alas! How could the foolish understand this principle? Their improper actions lead to their own suffering. Externally, they are harmed by wind, cold, heat, and humidity; internally, they suffer from hunger, fullness, and labor, which exhaust the proper body and diminish the proper spirit, binding and trapping themselves, leading to life and death being laid bare. The truths of life and death lie in the balance of yin and yang. Yin energy descends and does not rise, referred to as “cutting the channels”; yang energy ascends and does not descend, called “blocking the meridians.” The evil within yin is called turbid, while the evil within yang is called clear. Fire comes to the door of the Kan (water) while water reaches the gate of Li (fire). When yin and yang correspond with each other, there is harmony.[21p]

    阴不足则济之以水母，阳不足则济之以火精。阴阳济等，各有攀陵。上通三寸曰阳之神路，下通三寸曰阴之鬼程。阴常宜损，阳常宜盈。居之中者，阴阳匀停。是以阳中之阳，天仙赐号；阴中之阴，下鬼持名。顺阴者多消灭，顺阳者多长生。逢斯妙趣，无所不灵。　　阴阳者，天地之枢机；五行者，阴阳之终始。非阴阳则不能为天地，非五行则不能为阴阳。故人者成于天地，败于阴阳也，由五行逆从而生焉。天地有阴阳五行，人有血脉五脏。[22p]

    If yin is deficient, it is replenished with water essence; if yang is deficient, it is replenished with fire essence. The balance of yin and yang accounts for various ascent and descent. The upper passage of the yang spirit is three inches, while the lower passage of the yin spirit is also three inches. Yin should often be diminished, and yang should often be augmented. Between them lies balance, where yin and yang are harmonious. Therefore, the yang within yang is granted a title by the celestial beings, while the yin within yin is named by the earthly spirits. Those who follow yin often face depletion, while those who follow yang often attain longevity. Encountering this profound essence, there is nothing that does not resonate.

    Yin and yang are the mechanisms of heaven and earth; the five elements represent the beginning and end of yin and yang. Without yin and yang, heaven and earth cannot exist; without the five elements, yin and yang cannot manifest. Thus, human beings are formed by heaven and earth and fail through yin and yang, born from the reversals of the five elements. Heaven and earth possess yin, yang, and the five elements, just as humans possess blood vessels and vital organs.[22p]

    五行者，金木水火土也；五脏者，肺肝心肾脾也。金生水，水生木，木生火，火生土，土生金，则生成之道循环无穷。肺生肾，肾生肝，肝生心，心生脾，脾生肺，上下荣养，无有休息。故金匮至真要论云：心生血，血为肉之母；脾生肉，肉为血之舍；肺属气，气为骨之基；肾应骨，骨为筋之本；肝系筋，筋为血之源。五脏五行，相成相生。昼夜流转，无有始终。从之则吉，逆之则凶。天地阴阳，五行之道，中含于人。人得者可以出阴阳之数，夺天地之机，悦五行之要，无终无始，神仙不死矣。[23p]

    The five elements are metal, wood, water, fire, and earth; the five organs are the lungs, liver, heart, kidneys, and spleen. Metal generates water, water generates wood, wood generates fire, fire generates earth, and earth generates metal, thus the cycle of generation is endless. The lungs generate the kidneys, the kidneys generate the liver, the liver generates the heart, the heart generates the spleen, and the spleen generates the lungs, nourishing each other continuously without rest. Therefore, the "Golden Chamber's True Essentials" states: the heart produces blood, blood is the mother of flesh; the spleen generates flesh, flesh is the dwelling of blood; the lungs relate to qi, qi is the foundation of bones; the kidneys correspond to bones, bones are the source of tendons; the liver connects to tendons, tendons are the source of blood. The five organs and five elements support and generate each other. The cycle of day and night flows continuously without beginning or end. Following this brings good fortune, while going against it brings misfortune. The relationship between heaven and earth, yin and yang, and the path of the five elements is contained within humans. Those who understand this can navigate the numbers of yin and yang, seize the opportunities of heaven and earth, and align with the essence of the five elements, achieving eternal life without beginning or end.[23p]

    　　　　千金方 【唐　孙思邈】

    　　　　　养性论言

    　　扁鹊云：黄帝说昼夜漏下水百刻。凡一刻人百三十五息，十刻一千三百五十息，百刻一万三千五百息。人之居世，数息之间信哉！呜呼！昔人叹逝，何可不为善以自补邪？吾尝思一日一夜有十二时，十日十夜百二十时，百日百夜一千二百时，千日千夜一万二千时，万日万夜一十二万时，此为三十年。若长寿者九十年，只得三十六万时。百年之内，须臾之间，数时之活，朝菌蟪蛄不足为喻焉，可不自摄养？而驰骋六情，孜孜汲汲，追名逐利，千诈万巧，以求虚誉，没齿而无厌。故养性者，知其如此，于名于利若存若亡，于非名非利亦若存若亡，所以没身不殆也。[24p]

    On Maintaining One's Nature
    By Sun Simiao (Tang Dynasty)

    Bian Que said: The Yellow Emperor remarked that water drips down day and night at a rate of a hundred kè (刻). In a single kè, a person takes one hundred thirty-five breaths; in ten kè, one thousand three hundred fifty breaths; and in one hundred kè, ten thousand three hundred fifty breaths. In a person’s life, how many breaths are there! Alas! The ancients lamented over their passing; how can one not strive to do good to nourish themselves? I have pondered that in a day and night there are twelve hours, in ten days and nights there are one hundred twenty hours, in one hundred days and nights there are one thousand two hundred hours, in one thousand days and nights there are ten thousand two hundred hours, and in ten thousand days and nights there are one hundred twenty thousand hours. This accounts for thirty years. If a long-lived person lives ninety years, they would only have three hundred sixty thousand hours. Within a hundred years, in the fleeting moments, the span of life is like that of morning mushrooms and cicadas, hardly worth mentioning. Can one neglect self-cultivation? Yet one indulges in all desires, tirelessly seeking fame and profit, employing countless deceptions and craftiness to obtain false reputation, never satisfied until death. Therefore, the one who nurtures their nature knows this: whether fame or profit, it is as if they exist or do not exist; the same applies to what is not fame or profit. Thus, they live their life without peril.[24p]

    余慨时俗之多僻，皆放逸以殒亡，聊因暇日，粗述养性篇，用奖人伦之道。好事君子，与我同志焉！　　夫养性者，欲所习以成性，性自为善，不习无不利也。性既自善，内外百病，皆悉不生，祸乱灾害，亦无由作，此养性之大经也。善养性者，则治未病之病，是其义也。故养性者，不待饵药餐霞，其在兼于百行，百行周备，虽绝药饵，足以遐年。德行不充，纵服玉液金丹，未能延寿。故夫子曰：善摄生者，陆行不遇虎兕。此则道德之指也，岂假服饵而祈遐年哉？圣人所以制药饵者，以救过行之人也。故愚者抱病，历年而不修一行，缠疴没齿，终无悔心，此其所以岐和长逝，彭跗永归，良有以也。[25p]

    I lament the many deviations of contemporary customs, where indulgence leads to demise. Thus, during my leisure days, I will briefly outline a treatise on nurturing one’s nature, to encourage the path of human virtues. Esteemed gentlemen of good will, join me in this cause!

    To nurture one's nature means to cultivate it through practice; inherently, nature is good, and without practice, it is never beneficial. When nature is inherently good, inner and outer ailments will cease to manifest, and calamities and disasters will have no cause to arise. This is the great principle of nurturing one's nature. To nurture one's nature is to treat illnesses before they arise, and this is its significance. Therefore, nurturing one’s nature does not rely on medicinal pills or elixirs; it is found in the embrace of a multitude of virtuous actions. When virtuous actions are complete, though one may forsake medicine, one can enjoy longevity.

    Without a full measure of virtue, even consuming the finest elixirs cannot prolong life. Thus, the sage says: a person who knows how to preserve life will not encounter tigers or rhinoceroses on land. This, then, points to the essence of morality; how can one rely solely on pills to wish for a long life? The reason sages developed medicines is to aid those who have strayed from the right path. Hence, the foolish cling to their ailments, year after year neglecting the cultivation of a single virtue, becoming entangled in diseases without remorse, thus they meet with the inevitable end. This is the reason for their enduring decline and final return.[25p]

    嵇康曰：养生有五难，名利不去为一难，喜怒不除为二难，声色不去为三难，滋味不绝为四难，神虑精散为五难。五者必存，虽心希难老，口诵至言，咀嚼英华，呼吸太阳，不能不回其操，不夭其年也。五者无于胸中，则信顺日跻，道德日全，不祈善而有福，不求寿而自延，此养生之大旨也。然或有服膺仁义，无甚泰之累者，抑或其亚欤！　　仲长统曰：王侯之宫，美女兼千千：原作「于」，据《千金》卷二十七养性序改。；卿士之家，侍妾数百。昼则以醇酒淋其骨髓，夜则于房室输其血气。耳听淫声，目乐邪色，燕内不出，游外不返，王公得之于上，豪杰驰之于下。[26p]

    Ji Kang said: There are five difficulties in nurturing life. The first is the inability to let go of fame and profit; the second is the failure to eliminate joy and anger; the third is the attachment to sound and color; the fourth is the inability to end indulgence in flavors; the fifth is the scattering of the spirit and thoughts. If these five difficulties are present, even if one’s heart wishes to escape aging, and despite reciting profound words, savoring essence, and breathing in sunlight, one cannot avoid returning to one's habits, nor can one extend one's years. If these five are absent from one’s heart, then one will naturally ascend to virtue and integrity, blessings will come without seeking goodness, and longevity will manifest without striving for it. This is the great principle of nurturing life. Yet, there may be those who uphold benevolence and righteousness without heavy burdens; or are they merely a step below?

    Zhong Changtong said: In the palaces of kings and nobles, there are countless beautiful women; in the homes of high-ranking officials, there are hundreds of concubines. By day, they soak their bones in fine wine, and by night, they deplete their vital energy in their chambers. They listen to lewd sounds and delight in corrupt sights, never leaving their inner chambers and not returning from their external indulgences. The kings obtain this from above, and the heroes rush to follow suit from below.[26p]

    及至生产不时，字育太早，或童孺而擅气，或疾病而媾精，精气薄恶，血脉不充。既出胞脏，养护无法，又蒸之以绵纩，烁之以五味，胎伤孩病而脆，未得坚刚，复纵情欲，重重相生，病病相孕。国无良医，医无审术，奸佐其间，过谬常有，会有一疾，莫能自免。当今少百岁之人者，岂非所习不纯正也？　　抱朴子曰：或问所谓伤之者，岂色欲之间乎？答曰：亦何独斯哉！然长生之要，其在房中，上士知之，可以延年除病，其次不以自伐。若年当少壮而知还阴丹以补脑，采七益于长俗【一作谷】 者，不服药物，不失一二百岁也，但不得仙耳。不得其术者，古人方之于菱杯以盛酒，羽苞之蓄火。[27p]

    When production occurs at inopportune times, when offspring are birthed too early, whether children are too frail or if illness corrupts the essence, the vital essence is weak and the blood vessels lack sufficiency. Once born, there is no means for care or nourishment; moreover, they are steamed with cotton and refined with various flavors, causing the fetus to be damaged and the child to become sickly and delicate, unable to gain strength. If desires are indulged, they produce one another cyclically, leading to ailments that beget further ailments. When a nation lacks good doctors, and medicine lacks precise techniques, deception thrives among them, making mistakes commonplace; when an illness arises, no one can escape it. Are those who are under a hundred years old today not products of improper practices?

    The Baopuzi says: When one questions what it means to be harmed, is it not in the realm of sexual desire? The answer is: Is this the only aspect? Yet, the essence for longevity lies in the chamber; the wise know it can lengthen life and eliminate illness, while others should not boast of themselves. If at a young age, one knows to return to the essence to nourish the mind, and gathers benefits from the usual practices, without relying on medicine, they could live one or two hundred years, but cannot achieve immortality. Those who do not grasp the techniques should refer to ancient methods, like using a water lily cup to hold wine and the feathers of a bird to contain fire.[27p]

    又且才所不逮而强思之，伤也；力所不胜而强举之，伤也；深忧重恚，伤也；悲哀憔悴，伤也；喜乐过度，伤也；汲汲所欲，伤也；戚戚所患，伤也；久谈言笑，伤也；寝息失时，伤也；挽弓引弩，伤也；沉醉呕吐，伤也；饱食即卧，伤也；走跳喘乏，伤也；欢呼哭泣，伤也。积伤至尽，尽则早亡。尽则非道也。是以养性之士，唾不至远，行不疾步，耳不极听，目不极视，坐不久处，立不至疲，卧不至懻。先寒而衣，先热而解。不欲极饥而食，食不可过饱；不欲极渴而饮，饮不欲过多。饱食过多则结积聚，渴饮过多则成痰澼。[28p]

    Furthermore, forcing oneself to think beyond one's capabilities causes harm; exerting oneself beyond one's strength causes harm; deep worries and intense anger cause harm; sorrow and exhaustion cause harm; excessive joy and happiness cause harm; relentless pursuit of desires causes harm; persistent concerns and troubles cause harm; prolonged conversations and laughter cause harm; sleeping at improper times causes harm; stretching the bow and drawing the crossbow causes harm; excessive intoxication and vomiting cause harm; overeating and then lying down causes harm; running and jumping until breathless causes harm; excessive cheering and weeping cause harm. When accumulated injuries reach their peak, it leads to premature death. When it reaches such an end, it is not in accordance with the way. Therefore, those who nurture their health do not spit far, walk at a moderate pace, listen without straining, see without overstretching, sit for a limited time, stand without getting fatigued, and rest without worrying. They dress before it gets cold and remove layers before it gets hot. They do not wish to be extremely hungry before eating, nor should one eat to fullness; they do not want to be extremely thirsty before drinking, nor should one drink excessively. Overeating leads to stagnation, and excessive drinking leads to phlegm.[28p]

    不欲甚劳，不欲甚佚，不欲流汗，不欲多唾，不欲奔走车马，不欲极目远望，不欲多啖生冷，不欲饮酒当风，不欲数数沐浴，不欲广志远愿，不欲规造异巧。冬不欲极温，夏不欲穷凉。不欲露卧星月，不欲眠中用扇。大寒大热，大风大雾，皆不欲冒之。五味不欲偏多。故酸多则伤脾，苦多则伤肺，辛多则伤肝，咸多则伤心，甘多则伤肾。此五味克五脏，五行自然之理也。凡言伤者，亦不即觉也，谓久即损寿耳。是以善摄生者，卧起有四时之早晚，兴居有至和之常制。调利筋骨，有偃仰之方；祛疾闲邪，有吐纳之术；流行荣卫，有补泻之法；节宣劳佚，有与夺之要。忍怒以全阴，抑喜以养阳。然后先服草木以救亏缺，后服金丹以定无穷。养性之理，尽于此矣。[29p]

    Do not desire excessive labor, nor excessive idleness. Do not wish to sweat, nor to spit excessively. Do not wish to rush with carriages and horses, nor to gaze far into the distance. Do not wish to consume too much raw or cold food, nor to drink alcohol in the wind. Do not wish to bathe repeatedly, nor to have broad ambitions and distant wishes. In winter, do not desire excessive warmth; in summer, do not seek extreme coolness. Do not wish to sleep exposed under the stars and moon, nor to use a fan while sleeping. Be cautious of extreme cold and heat, strong winds and fog; do not expose yourself to them.

    Do not favor any single flavor excessively. Too much sourness harms the spleen; excessive bitterness damages the lungs; too much spiciness injures the liver; overindulgence in salt affects the heart; excessive sweetness harms the kidneys. The five flavors control the five organs; this is the principle of nature. When it is said that something causes harm, it is not immediately felt, but rather, over time, it affects longevity. Thus, those who are skilled at nurturing life have routines for waking and sleeping in harmony with the seasons, and maintain a constant balance in their activities.

    They adjust and enable the muscles and bones with proper postures; they dispel diseases and idle evils with breathing techniques; they allow for circulation of nourishment and defense using methods for supplementation and depletion; they balance effort with rest by understanding the nature of gain and loss. They restrain anger to preserve yin and suppress joy to nurture yang. Thus, they first consume herbs and plants to remedy deficiencies, and later use elixirs to secure endlessness. The principles of nurturing one’s nature conclude here.[29p]

    夫欲快意任怀，自谓达识知命不泥异端，极性肆力不劳持久者，闻此言也，虽风之过耳，电之惊目，不足喻也。虽身枯于留连之中，气绝于绮纨之际，而甘心焉，亦安可告之以养性之事哉？匪惟不纳，乃谓妖讹也，而望彼信之？所谓以明鉴给蒙瞽，以丝竹娱聋夫者也。　　魏武与皇甫隆令曰：闻卿年出百岁，而体力不衰，耳目聪明，颜色和悦，此盛事也，所服食施行导引，可得闻乎？者有可传，想可密封示内。隆上疏对曰：臣闻天地之性，惟人为贵。人知所贵，莫贵于生。荒唐无始，劫运无穷。人生其间，忽如电过。每一思此，惘然心热。生不再来，逝不可追。何不抑情养性以自保惜？今四海垂定，太平之际，又当须展才布德，当由万年。万年无穷，当由修道。[30p]

    To pursue desires and indulge one's sentiments, believing oneself to possess discernment and to know fate without sticking to heterodox views, and to push the limits of one's nature with ease without the effort of perseverance—upon hearing these words, it is merely like the wind passing by the ear or the lightning startling the eye, insufficient to convey understanding. Even if one's body withers in indulgence and one’s spirit fades amidst luxury, if one rejoices in it, how can one speak of nurturing one’s nature? Not only do they refuse to accept this, but they also call it an error and expect others to believe it? It is like using clear mirrors to enlighten the blind, or playing music to entertain the deaf.

    Wei Wu summoned Huangfu Long and said: “I have heard you have reached a hundred years of age, yet your body remains strong, your hearing and sight are sharp, and your complexion is lively and pleasant—this is a remarkable thing. May I ask what you eat and what exercises you perform?” There is something worthy of being passed down; I imagine it could be sealed and shared privately.

    Long submitted a response saying: “I have heard that of all things in heaven and earth, humanity is of greatest value. Among what people value, nothing is more precious than life. Life is chaotic and without beginning, and calamity is endless. Life happens in the midst of this, fleeting like lightning. Each time I ponder this, my heart feels greatly troubled. Life does not come again; the departed cannot be pursued. Why not suppress desires and nurture one’s nature to preserve and cherish oneself? Now that the four seas are settled and in a time of peace, one ought to display talents and virtues, aiming for a longevity of ten thousand years. Ten thousand years without end must be derived from cultivating the Way.”[30p]

    道甚易知，但莫能行。臣常闻道人蒯京已年一百七十八而甚丁壮，言人当朝朝服食玉泉，琢齿，使丁壮人有颜色，去三虫而坚齿。玉泉者，口中唾也。朝旦未起，早漱津令满口，乃吞之；琢齿二七遍。如此者，乃名曰炼精。　　抱朴子曰：一人之身，一国之象也。胸腹之位，犹宫室也；四肢之列，犹郊境也；骨节之分，犹百官也。神犹君也，血犹臣也，气犹民也。知治身则能治国也。夫爱其民，所以安其国；惜其气，所以全其身。民散则国亡，气竭则身死。死者不可生也，亡者不可存也。是以至人消未起之患，治未病之疾，医之于无事之前，不追于既逝之后。夫人难养而易危也，气难清而易浊也。故能审威德，所以保社稷；割嗜欲，所以固血气。然后真一存焉，精神守焉，百病却焉，年寿延焉。[31p]

    The Way is very easy to understand, but few can practice it. I have often heard that the person known as Daoist Kuai Jing is 178 years old and still very robust. He says that people should regularly consume the essence of jade spring in the morning and polish their teeth to maintain a healthy appearance, which eliminates the three pests and strengthens the teeth. The jade spring refers to saliva. Before rising in the morning, one should rinse the mouth until it is full and then swallow it; polish the teeth 27 times. This practice is called refining one’s essence.

    The Book of Embracing Simplicity states: "A person's body is like a country. The position of the chest and abdomen resembles palaces and halls; the arrangement of the limbs resembles the borders of the country; the joints are like the officials." The spirit is akin to the ruler, the blood is like the subjects, and the breath is like the people. To know how to govern oneself is to know how to govern a state. To love one's people is to secure the nation; to cherish one’s breath is to preserve one’s life. When the people disperse, the nation perishes; when the breath depletes, life ends. The dead cannot be revived, and the lost cannot be retained. Thus, the enlightened person addresses problems before they arise, treats ailments before they develop, and heals when there is no trouble, rather than waiting until after it has already passed.

    Man is difficult to nurture yet easy to endanger; breath is hard to purify yet easy to foul. Therefore, one must be discerning in authority and virtue to protect the state; curb desires to solidify one’s health. Only then can the true unity be preserved, the spirit safeguarded, a myriad of diseases repelled, and longevity extended.[31p]

    　　　　　道林养性

    　　虽尝服饵，而不知养性之术，亦难以长生也。养性之道，常欲小劳，但莫大疲及强所不能堪耳。且流水不腐，户枢不蠹，以其运动故也。养性之道，莫久行、久立、久坐、久卧、久视、久听。盖以久视伤血，久卧伤气，久立伤骨，久坐伤肉，久行伤筋也。仍莫强食，莫强酒，莫强举重，莫忧思，莫大怒，莫悲愁，莫大惧，莫跳踉，莫多言，莫大笑。勿汲汲于所欲，勿悁悁怀忿恨。皆损寿命，若能不犯者，则得长生也。[32p]

    Nurturing the Nature within the Dao

    Even if one has taken herbal medicine, without knowing the art of nurturing one's nature, it is also difficult to attain long life. The way of nurturing nature requires small efforts but must avoid great fatigue and exceeding one's limits. Just as flowing water does not stagnate and the hinges of a door do not rot due to their movement, so too must one move to nurture life.

    The way of nurturing life avoids prolonged standing, being stationary, sitting, lying down, staring, or listening. This is because prolonged staring harms the blood, lying harms the vital energy, standing harms the bones, sitting harms the flesh, and walking harms the muscles. One should also avoid overeating, overdrinking, excessively lifting weights, worry, intense anger, profound sorrow, great fear, stumbling, excessive talking, and loud laughter.

    One should not be overly eager for desires and should not harbor resentment and hatred. All these diminish life expectancy; if one can avoid them, then longevity can be attained.[32p]

    故善摄生者，常少思、少念、少欲、少事、少语、少笑、少愁、少乐、少喜、少怒、少好、少恶，行此十二少者，养性之都契也。多思则神殆，多念则志散，多欲则志昏，多事则形劳，多语则气乏，多笑则脏伤，多愁则心慑，多乐则意溢，多喜则忘错昏乱，多怒则百脉不定，多好则专迷不理，多恶则憔悴无欢，此十二多不除，则荣卫失度，血气妄行，丧生之本也。惟无多无少者，几于道矣。是知勿外缘者，真人初学道之法也。若能如此者，可居瘟疫之中，无忧疑矣。[33p]

    Thus, those who are adept at preserving life should always think less, contemplate less, desire less, engage in fewer matters, speak less, laugh less, worry less, enjoy less, rejoice less, get angry less, like less, and dislike less. Practicing these twelve reductions is the supreme way to nurture one’s character. Excessive thinking endangers the spirit, excessive contemplation scatters the will, excessive desire clouds the intention, excessive engagement tires the body, excessive talking depletes the energy, excessive laughter harms the organs, excessive worry frightens the heart, excessive joy overfills the consciousness, excessive rejoicing leads to confusion and mistakes, excessive anger disrupts the pulse, excessive liking causes obsession, and excessive disliking exhausts one and brings no joy. If these twelve excesses are not eliminated, then the balance of vitality and the blood will be disturbed, which jeopardizes the essence of life. Only when one transcends both excess and deficiency can one be close to the Way. Therefore, understanding not to rely on external conditions is the method for genuine practitioners at the beginning of their journey. If one can achieve this, they can dwell amidst epidemics without worry or doubt.[33p]

    既屏外缘，会须守五神【肝心脾肺肾，】 　四正 【言行坐立，】 言最不得浮思妄念，心想欲事，恶邪大起。故孔子曰：思无邪也。常当习黄帝内视法，存想思念，令见五脏如悬罄，五色了了分明，勿辍也。仍于每旦初起，面向午，展两手于膝上，心眼观气上入顶，下达涌泉，旦旦如此，名曰迎气。常以鼻引气，口吐气，小微吐之，不得开口；复欲得出气少，入气多，每欲食，迸气入腹，每欲食气为主人也。凡心有所爱不用深爱，有所憎不用深憎，并皆损性伤神。[34p]

    After shutting out external distractions, one must guard the five inner organs: the liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys. One's actions and words must be upright; it is essential that thoughts do not wander into idle or delusional ideas, for if the heart is preoccupied with desires, evil thoughts will arise. Therefore, Confucius said: "Think without malice." One should regularly practice the Inner Vision method of the Yellow Emperor, focusing on visualization and contemplation, ensuring that the five organs are perceived as if suspended and that the five colors are clear and distinct—this practice should not be neglected.

    Every morning upon rising, face south, spread both hands on your knees, and observe the flow of energy moving up to the crown and down to the bubbling spring (the soles of your feet); repeat this daily; it is called "welcoming the Qi." Regularly inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth in a calm and gentle manner, without opening the mouth too wide. If you wish to exhale less and inhale more, each time you eat, breathe energy into the abdomen, while the inhaled energy acts as the master. Whatever you love in your heart, do not express excessive love, and whatever you dislike, do not express excessive disdain, as both will harm your nature and spirit.[34p]

    亦不用深赞，亦不用深毁。常思运心于物平等，如觉偏颇，寻改正之。居贫勿谓常贫，居富勿谓常富。居贫富之中，常须守道。勿以贫富易志改性。识达道理，似不能言。有大功德，勿自矜伐。美药勿离手，善言勿离口，乱想勿经心。常以深心至诚，恭敬于物；慎勿诈善，以悦于人。终身为善。为人所嫌，勿得起恨。事君尽礼，人以为谄，当以道自平其心。道之所在，其德不孤。勿言行善不得善报，以自怨雠。居处勿令心有不足，若有不足，则自抑之，勿令得起。人知止足，天遗其禄。[35p]

    There is no need for deep praise, nor for deep criticism. Always contemplate the equality of your heart towards things; if you sense bias, seek to correct it. If living in poverty, do not claim to be permanently poor; if living in wealth, do not claim to be permanently rich. In the midst of poverty and wealth, always uphold the path. Do not let changes in wealth alter your aspirations or character. Understanding profound principles may seem inexpressible. If you have great virtues, do not boast about them. Keep good remedies close and wise words on your lips; do not dwell on chaotic thoughts. Always approach matters with deep sincerity and respect; be cautious not to feign goodness to please others. Be virtuous throughout your life. If others dislike you, do not let hatred arise. Serve your lord with full courtesy, and if others perceive it as flattery, adjust your heart according to the way. Where the way resides, virtue is not lonely. Do not say that doing good does not bring good rewards, lest you harbor resentment. In your dwelling place, do not let your heart feel lacking; if you sense a lack, suppress it and do not allow it to grow. Those who know contentment are rewarded by heaven.[35p]

    所至之处，勿得多求，多求则心自疲而志益苦。夫人之所以多病，当由不能养性。平康之日，谓言常然，纵情恣欲，心所欲得，则便为之，不拘禁忌，欺罔幽明，无所不作，自言适性。不知过后，一一皆为病本。及两手摸空，白汗流出，口唱皇天，无所逮及。皆以生平粗心，不能自察，一至于此。但能少时内省身心，则自知见行之中，皆畏诸疴，将知四百四病，身手自造，本非由天。及一朝病发，和缓不救，方更诽谤医药无效，神仙无灵。[36p]

    Wherever one goes, one should not seek too much; if one seeks too much, the heart becomes weary and the will increasingly suffers. The reason people are often ill is that they cannot nurture their nature. In times of health, they may indulge their desires, striving to obtain what their hearts seek, without restraint or regard for prohibitions, deceiving themselves and others, acting in every manner they wish, thinking they are true to their nature. Unbeknownst to them, in the aftermath, all these become the roots of their illnesses. When they find their hands empty and white sweat flowing out, they lament to the heavens, realizing they can grasp nothing. This is due to having been heedless throughout life, lacking self-examination, until it reaches this point. If they could take time for inner reflection, they would realize that in their actions, they fear all illnesses, and would come to understand the four hundred and four types of sickness, which they create themselves, and that these are not caused by heaven. When one day illness strikes and fails to improve, they then slander medicine as ineffective and dismiss the immortals as unresponsive.[36p]

    故有智之人，爱惜性命者，当自思念，深生耻愧，诫勒身心，常修善事也。至于居处不得绮靡华丽，今人贪婪无厌，乃患害之源。但令雅素净洁，无风雨寒湿为佳。衣服器械，勿用珍玉金宝；增长过失，使人烦恼根深。厨膳勿脯肉丰盈，常令俭约为佳。然后行作鹅王步，语作含钟声，眠作狮子卧【右脚胁着地坐脚也】 。每日自咏歌云：美食须熟嚼，生食不粗吞。间我居止处，大宅总林村。胎息守五脏，气至骨成仙。又歌曰：日食三个毒，不嚼而自消。锦绣为五脏，身着粪扫袍。修心既平，又须慎言语。[37p]

    Therefore, wise individuals who cherish their lives should reflect deeply, feel a profound sense of shame and guilt, discipline their bodies and minds, and continually cultivate good deeds. When it comes to dwelling, one should avoid extravagant luxuries; the greed and insatiability of modern people are the sources of suffering. It is best if one keeps their residence elegant, simple, and clean, without exposure to wind, rain, cold, or dampness. Clothing and utensils should not be made of precious jewels or gold; excessive indulgence leads to deep-rooted worries. Meals should not be abundant with rich meats; a frugal lifestyle is preferable. Then one can walk like a majestic swan, speak as if resonating with a bell, and sleep like a lion. Each day, one should sing: "Delicious food must be chewed well; do not swallow raw food without savoring." In my dwelling place, it’s a large house surrounded by forests and villages. By nurturing vitality and guarding the five organs, one's energy may reach the bones, achieving a form of immortality. Additionally, one should sing: "Three forms of poison are consumed each day; if not chewed, they will dissolve by themselves." Embellishments are for the five organs; one dresses in humble garments. Having a calm mind, one must also speak cautiously.[37p]

    凡言语诵读，常想声在气海中【脐下也】 。每日初入后，勿言语读诵，宁待平旦也。旦起欲专言善事，不欲先计较钱财。又食上不得语，语而食者，常患胸背痛。亦不用寝卧多言笑，寝不得语言者，言五脏如钟磬，不悬则不可发声。行不得语，若欲语须住脚乃语，行语则令人失气。冬至日止可语，不可言。自言曰言，答人曰语。言有人来问，不可不答，自不可发言也。仍勿触冷，开口大语为佳。言语既慎，却节饮食。是以善养性者，先饥而食，先渴而饮。[38p]

    Whenever speaking or reciting, one should often contemplate the voice residing in the lower energy center (just below the navel). Each day, upon first entering, one should avoid speaking or reciting until dawn. When rising at dawn, one should focus on discussing virtuous matters, avoiding any concerns about money first. Furthermore, one should not speak while eating; those who do often suffer from chest and back pain. It is also advised not to engage in excessive talking or laughter while lying down; if one cannot remain silent in bed, the internal organs are likened to bells or chimes, which cannot resonate if not suspended properly. Speaking while walking is discouraged; if speech is necessary, one should pause and then speak, as speaking while moving can lead to a loss of energy. On the Winter Solstice, one may speak but should refrain from excessive conversation. When someone inquires, one should not refuse to answer, but one should also avoid unnecessary speech. Furthermore, one should avoid exposure to cold and prefer to speak with intention. Once one's speech is cautious, it is best to moderate food and drink. Therefore, those who nurture their nature wisely eat when hungry and drink when thirsty.[38p]

    食欲数而少，不欲顿而多，则难消也。常欲令如饱中饥、饥中饱耳。盖饱则伤肺，饥则伤气，咸则伤筋，酸则伤骨。故每学淡食，食当熟嚼，使米脂入腹，勿使酒脂入肠。人之当食，须去烦恼。如食五味，必不得暴嗔，多令人神惊，夜梦飞扬。每食不用重肉，喜生百病。常须少食肉，多食饭，及少葅菜，并勿食生菜、生米、小豆陈臭物，勿饮浊酒食面，使塞气孔。勿食生肉伤胃。一切肉惟须煮烂，停冷食之。食毕当漱口数过，令人牙齿不败，口香。热食讫，以冷酢浆漱口者，令人口气常臭，作(上匿下虫)齿病。[39p]

    When appetite is limited and one desires not to eat much at once, it becomes difficult to digest. One often seeks to feel as if one is full while still being hungry, or hungry while still feeling full. For fullness can harm the lungs, while hunger can sap energy; salty flavors may harm the tendons, and sour flavors can affect the bones. Therefore, one should generally practice a light diet, ensuring that food is well-chewed so that the rice essence enters the stomach, and not let the essence of wine enter the intestines. When one eats, it is essential to remove worries. Consuming the five flavors should not lead to excessive anger, as this can easily disturb the spirit and cause restless dreams at night. One should not indulge in heavy meats, which often lead to various ailments. It is advisable to eat less meat, more rice, and a small amount of vegetables, while avoiding raw vegetables, raw rice, spoiled beans, and unclean things, and not to drink murky wines or eat dough that blocks the airways. Raw meat should not be consumed as it can damage the stomach. All meat should be thoroughly cooked and allowed to cool before eating. After eating, one should rinse the mouth several times to prevent dental decay and maintain fresh breath. Rinsing the mouth with cold vinegar after eating hot food can result in foul breath and dental issues.[39p]

    又诸热食咸物后，不得饮冷酢浆水，喜失声成尸咽。凡热食汗出，勿当风，发痉头痛，令人目濇多睡。每食讫以手摩面及腹，令津液通流。食毕当行步踌躇，计人行数里来，行毕，使人以粉摩腹上数百遍，则食易消，大益人，令人能饮食，无百病，然后有所修为为快也。饱食即卧，乃生百病，不消成积聚。饱食仰卧，成气痞，作头风。触寒来者寒未解，食热食，成刺风。人不得夜食。又云夜勿过醉饱。食勿精思。为劳苦事有损，余虚损人。[40p]

    After consuming hot foods and salty items, one should not drink cold vinegar or thin water, as this can lead to losing one's voice and throat constriction. When sweating from hot foods, do not expose yourself to the wind, as it can cause spasms and headaches, leading to watery eyes and excessive sleepiness. After finishing a meal, one should rub their face and abdomen with their hands to help the flow of bodily fluids. After eating, it is important to walk about casually, and if one walks several miles, then having someone massage the abdomen hundreds of times can aid digestion, greatly benefiting one’s health and allowing for the enjoyment of food without illness. Eating until full and then lying down can lead to various ailments, causing food to stagnate and accumulate. Lying on one's back after a full meal can result in a gas-filled stomach, leading to headaches. Exposure to cold after consuming hot food can give rise to colds. One should not eat at night, nor should one overindulge in food and drink at night. Avoid excessive contemplation while eating. Engaging in laborious tasks is harmful, draining one's energy.[40p]

    常须日在巳时食讫，则不须饮酒，终身无干呕。勿食父母本命所属肉，令人命不长。勿食自己本命所属肉，令人魂魄飞扬。勿食一切脑，大损人。茅屋漏水，堕诸脯肉上，食之成瘕癖。暴肉作脯不肯干者害人。祭神肉无故自动，食之害人。饮食上蜂行住，食之有毒害人。腹内有宿病，勿食鲮鲤鱼肉害人。湿食及酒浆，临上看视，不见人物影者，勿食之，成卒注。若已食腹胀者，急以药下之。每十日一食葵。葵滑所以通五脏壅气，又是菜之主，不用合心食之。[41p]

    One must eat before the sun reaches the hour of the snake; then there is no need to drink alcohol, and one will be free from nausea for life. Do not eat the flesh associated with your parents' birth fate, as it shortens one's life. Do not eat the flesh associated with your own birth fate, as it causes the soul to drift away. Avoid all brains, as they greatly harm a person. If rain seeps into a thatched hut and falls on preserved meats, consuming them leads to lumps in the body. Fresh meat that has not been properly dried is harmful. Eating meat from offerings made to deities that moves on its own is detrimental. If insects are found in food, do not consume it, as it is toxic. If one has a chronic illness, do not eat carp or catfish, as they cause harm. Foods that are damp or trodden upon by someone and are not visibly affected should not be eaten, as it leads to sudden conditions. If one feels abdominal swelling after eating, medicine should be taken promptly. Eat malva every ten days, as it helps to relieve the blockage of the five viscera and is a leading vegetable; there’s no need to combine it with other foods for better effects.[41p]

    又饮酒不欲使多，多则速吐之为佳，勿令至醉，即终身百病不除。久饮酒者，腐烂肠胃，渍髓蒸筋，伤神损寿。醉不可当风向阳，令人发狂；又不可当风卧，不可令人扇凉，皆即得病也。醉不可露卧及卧黍穰中，发癞疮。醉不可强食，或发痈疽，或发喑，或生疮。醉饱不可以走车马及跳踯。醉不可以接房，醉饱交接，小者面(黑干)咳嗽，大者伤绝脏脉损命。凡人饥欲坐小便，若饱则立小便，慎之无病。又忍尿不便，膝冷成痹；忍大便不出，成气痔。[42p]

    When drinking alcohol, one should not overindulge; if one drinks too much, it's better to vomit it up. Avoid getting drunk, as it can lead to lifelong ailments. Prolonged drinking can rot the intestines and stomach, seep into the marrow and muscles, harm the spirit, and reduce lifespan. When drunk, do not face the wind or the sun, as it can drive one to madness; also, do not lie in the wind or be fanned, as this can lead to illness. When intoxicated, do not sleep exposed or among millet, or you may develop sores. Do not force yourself to eat while drunk, or you may develop boils, lose your voice, or get sores. Being drunk and overly full, one should not attempt to ride in a vehicle or jump around. Furthermore, do not engage in intimate relations while drunk and overly full; minor issues may lead to coughing, while major ones may damage organs and threaten life. When a person feels the urge to urinate while hungry, they should sit; if they feel full, they should stand. Be cautious to avoid sickness. Additionally, holding in urine can lead to coldness in the knees and numbness, while holding in a bowel movement can lead to hemorrhoids.[42p]

    小便勿努，令两足及膝冷；大便不用呼气及强努，令人腰疼目濇，宜任之佳。凡遇山水坞中出泉者，不可久居常食，作瘿病。又深阴地冷水不可饮，必作痎疟。饮食以调，时慎脱着。凡人旦起着衣，反者便着之，吉。衣光者，当户三振之，曰殃去，吉。湿衣及汗衣，皆不可久着，令人发疮及风瘙。大汗能易衣佳，不易者急洗之，不尔令人小便不利。凡大汗勿偏脱衣，喜得偏风半身不遂。春天不可薄衣，令人伤寒霍乱，食不消头痛。脱着既时，须调寝处。凡人卧，春夏向东，秋冬向西。头勿北卧，及墙北亦勿安床。凡欲睡，勿歌咏不祥。[43p]

    Do not strain while urinating, as it may cause coldness in the legs and knees; when defecating, do not use force or hold your breath, as this can lead to lower back pain and eye issues—allow it to happen naturally. Whenever encountering springs in valleys or mountainous areas, do not stay long or eat regularly there, as it may lead to goiter disease. Moreover, avoid drinking cold water from deep, shady places, as it can cause epidemic fevers. Eat and drink in moderation, and be mindful of dressing appropriately for the weather.

    When a person rises in the morning, if they dress in reverse, it is auspicious to wear it that way. For bright clothes, they should be shaken three times at the entrance, saying "misfortune be gone," which is auspicious. Wet or sweaty clothes should not be worn for long, as they may lead to sores and skin itchiness. If one sweats profusely, it is best to change clothes; if that is not possible, wash them promptly, or it may result in urinary difficulties. In cases of heavy sweating, do not only remove clothes from one side, as this could invite half- winds and cause one side of the body to become paralyzed.

    In spring, do not wear thin clothing, as it may result in colds and digestive issues. After changing clothes, one should adjust their sleeping environment accordingly. Generally, during sleep, one should face east in spring and summer, and west in autumn and winter. The head should not face north, nor should the bed be positioned against the north wall. When about to sleep, do not sing or chant, as it invites misfortune.[43p]

    起上床坐，先脱左足。卧勿当舍脊下。卧讫，勿留灯烛，令魂魄及六神不安，多愁怨。人头边勿安火炉，日久引火气，头重目赤睛，及鼻干。夜卧，当耳勿有孔吹人，即耳聋。夏不用露面卧，令人面皮厚，喜成癣，或作面风。冬夜勿覆头，得长寿。凡人眠勿以脚悬踏高处，久成肾水，及损房。足冷人，每见十步直墙，勿顺墙卧，风利吹人发癫；及体重人卧勿跂床悬脚，久成血痹，两足重腰疼。又不得昼眠，令人失气。卧勿大语，损人气力。[44p]

    When getting into bed, first remove your left foot. Do not lie directly on your back with your spine exposed. After lying down, do not leave lamps or candles burning, as they disturb the spirit and the six senses, leading to excessive sorrow and resentment. Do not place a stove by your head, as prolonged exposure can generate heat, causing heaviness in the head, red eyes, and a dry nose. At night, ensure there are no drafts blowing into your ears, as this may lead to deafness. In summer, do not sleep with your face exposed, as it can cause thickening of the skin, lead to scabs, or create facial wind. In winter nights, do not cover your head, for it leads to longevity. Generally, when sleeping, do not let your feet hang over the edge, as this can cause kidney issues and damage to reproductive health. If your feet are cold, avoid sleeping along a straight wall over extended distances, as cold winds can disturb your mind; heavy-bodied individuals should not dangle their feet while sleeping, as this can lead to blood stasis and lower back pain. Additionally, avoid sleeping during the day, as it can cause depletion of vital energy. Do not speak loudly while lying down, as it can deplete your strength.[44p]

    暮卧常习闭口，口开即失气；且邪恶从口入，久而成消渴及失血色。屈膝侧卧，益人气力，胜正偃卧。按孔子不尸卧，故曰睡不厌踧，觉不厌舒。凡人舒睡则有鬼怪邪魔。凡眠先卧心，后卧眼。人卧一夜，当作五度反复，常逐更转。凡人夜魔，忽然灯唤之，定死无疑；暗唤之吉，亦不得近前急唤。夜梦恶，不须说，旦以水面东方噀之，咒曰：恶梦着草木，好梦成宝玉，即无咎矣。又梦之善恶，并勿说为吉。衣食寝处皆适，能顺时气者，始尽养生之道。故善摄生者，无犯日月之忌，无失岁时之和。[45p]

    At dusk, it is customary to keep the mouth closed; if it opens, one loses energy. Furthermore, evil enters through the mouth, leading over time to thirst and a loss of vitality. Lying on one's side with knees bent benefits one’s energy and is superior to lying flat. Confucius prohibited lying flat, hence it is said that sleep should not be overly constrained, and waking should not be excessively stretched. For an ordinary person, sleeping soundly can attract ghosts and evils. When sleeping, one should first settle the heart, then the eyes. During a night’s sleep, one should spend time turning over five times, constantly shifting positions. If one is suddenly awakened by a light in the night, it is certain death; if called in darkness, it is also ill to respond hastily. Nightmares should not be mentioned; in the morning, one should splash water towards the east and chant: "May bad dreams turn to grass and trees, and good dreams turn to precious jade," thus avoiding misfortune. Additionally, whether dreams are good or bad, do not mention them as auspicious. Clothing, food, and dwelling should all be appropriate, adapting to the seasonal energy, which is the essence of the way to nurture life. Therefore, those who are good at preserving life do not transgress the taboos of the sun and moon and do not disrupt the harmony of the seasons.[45p]

    须一日之忌，暮无饱食；一月之忌，晦无大醉；一岁之忌，暮无远行；终身之忌，暮无然烛行房，暮常护气也。凡气冬至起于涌泉，十一月至膝，十二月至股，五月至腰，名三阳成。二月至髆，三月至项，四月至顶，纯阳用事。阴亦仿此。故四月十月不得入房，避阴阳纯用事之月也。每冬至日，于北壁下厚铺草而卧，云受元气。每八月一日已后，即微火暖足，勿令下冷无生意，常欲使气在下，不欲泄于上。春冻未泮，衣欲下厚上薄。[46p]

    One must observe a day's abstinence and not feast in the evening; a month's abstinence and not get drunk on the last day; a year's abstinence and not travel far in the evening; and a lifetime's abstinence and not engage in candlelit activities in the evening, continually protecting one's vital energy. The vital energy begins at winter solstice, rising from the Yongquan point; in November, it reaches the knees, in December, the thighs, and in May, the waist, known as the formation of the three Yangs. In February, it reaches the heel; in March, the neck; in April, the crown — the pure Yang takes action. The Yin follows a similar pattern. Therefore, in the months of April and October, one should refrain from going into the bedroom, avoiding the use of Yin and Yang during these months of pure activity. Every winter solstice, one should lie on thick grass laid out on the northern wall, as it is said to absorb the original energy. After the first day of August, one should use a mild fire to warm the feet, not allowing the lower body to cool unfavorably — one always wishes for the energy to remain low, not to dissipate upward. In early spring, before the thaw, clothing should be thick at the bottom and thin at the top.[46p]

    养阳收阴，继世长生；养阴收阳，祸则灭门。故云冬时天地气闭，血气伏藏，人不可作劳出汗，发泄阳气，有损于人也。又云冬日冻脑，春秋脑足俱冻，此圣人之常法也。春欲晏卧早起，夏及秋欲侵夜乃卧早起，冬欲早卧而晏起，皆益人。虽云早起，莫在鸡鸣前；虽言晏起，莫在日出后。凡冬月忽有大热之时，夏月忽有大凉之时，皆勿受之。人有患天行时气者，皆由犯此也。即须调气息，使寒热平和，即免患也。每当腊日，勿歌舞，犯者必凶。常于正月寅日，烧白发吉。凡寅日剪手甲，午日剪足甲，又烧白发吉。[47p]

    Nourish yang and conserve yin, to perpetuate life and ensure longevity; nourish yin and conserve yang, leads to ruin and destruction. Therefore, it is said that during winter, the energies of heaven and earth are closed, and the blood and vital energy are concealed. One should not exert oneself to the point of sweating, as it releases yang energy and can be detrimental to health. It is also said that during winter, the brain can freeze; in spring and autumn, both the brain and body can be frozen—this is the constant practice of the sages.

    In spring, one should rise early and lie down late; in summer and autumn, one should stay up late before retiring; in winter, one should go to bed early and get up late, all of which are beneficial. Although one may say to rise early, it should not be before the rooster crows; and although one may say to rise late, it should not be after sunrise.

    Whenever there is an unexpected heat during the winter months or an unexpected chill during the summer months, one should not expose oneself. Those who suffer from climatic disturbances do so because they violate these principles. One must regulate one's breathing and balance the cold and heat to avoid afflictions.

    On the days of the winter solstice, do not sing or dance; those who do so will surely face calamity. Always burn white hair on the first day of the first month for good fortune. On the first day of the tiger (Yin), cut your fingernails; on the first day of the horse (Wu), cut your toenails, and also burn white hair for good fortune.[47p]

    　　　　　居处法

    　　凡人居止之室，必须周密，勿令有细隙，致有风气得入；少觉有风，勿强忍久坐，必须急急避之；久居不觉，使人中风。古来忽得偏风，四肢不随，或如角弓反张，或失音不语者，皆由忽此耳。身既中风，诸病总集，邪气得便，遭此致卒者，十中有九。是以大须周密，无得轻之，慎焉慎焉！所居之室，勿塞井及水渎，令人聋盲。[48p]

    Residence Guidelines

    For anyone's living space, it must be well-sealed; do not allow any small gaps that wind might enter through. If you feel even a slight draft, do not force yourself to remain seated for long; you must urgently seek to avoid it. Prolonged exposure without noticing can lead to a stroke. Historically, sudden gusts of wind have caused limbs to become unresponsive, creating conditions where one cannot speak or may feel as if their body is bending back like a bow. All of this results from neglecting this issue. Once afflicted by wind, many ailments can converge, and the presence of harmful energies can lead to sudden death in nine out of ten cases. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain thorough precautions; do not take this lightly. Exercise extreme care! Additionally, ensure your living space does not block wells and waterways, as this can cause deafness and blindness.[48p]

    　　凡在家及外行，卒逢大飘风暴雨，震电昏暗大雾，此皆是诸龙鬼神行动经过所致，宜入室闭户，烧香静坐，安心以避之，待过后乃出，不尔损人。或当时虽未苦，于后不佳矣。又阴雾中亦不可远行。　　凡家中有经像，行来，先拜之，然后拜尊长，每行至则峻坐焉。　　凡居家不欲数沐浴。若沐浴必须密室，不得大热，亦不得大冷。皆生百病。冬浴不必汗出霢霂，沐浴后不得触风冷。新沐发讫，勿当风，勿湿荣髻，勿湿头卧，使人头风眩闷，发秃面黑，齿痛耳聋，头生白屑。饥忌浴，饱忌沐。沐讫须进少许食饮乃出。夜沐发不食即卧，令人心虚，饶汗多梦。[49p]

    When at home or outdoors, if one is caught in a great storm with strong winds and heavy rain, thunder and lightning, dense darkness and fog, this is caused by the movements of various dragons, spirits, and deities. It is advisable to enter a room, close the doors, burn incense, sit quietly, and find peace to avoid danger, waiting for the storm to pass before venturing out; otherwise, it will harm people. Though one might not suffer at the moment, later repercussions could arise. Also, it is inadvisable to travel far in foggy weather.

    In a household with sacred images, one should first bow to them before bowing to elders; whenever one moves, sit up straight and proper.

    In general, one should not bathe frequently at home. If one must bathe, it should be done in a private room; the water should not be too hot or too cold, or it could lead to numerous ailments. In winter, bathing should not necessarily induce heavy sweating; after bathing, one must avoid exposure to cold winds. After washing one's hair, one should not be exposed to wind, should not wet their hairstyle, nor allow their head to be damp while lying down, as this can cause dizziness, baldness, darkened complexion, toothaches, hearing loss, and dandruff. It is advised not to bathe when hungry or to bathe after a full meal. After bathing, one should eat a small amount before going out. Bathing at night without eating will lead to restlessness, excessive sweating, and vivid dreams.[49p]

    又夫妻不用同日沐浴，常以晦日浴，朔日沐，吉。凡炊汤经宿用洗体成癣，洗面无光，洗脚即疼痛，作甑畦疮。热泔洗头，冷水濯之，作头风。饮水沐头，亦作头风。时行病，新汗解，勿冷水洗浴，损心包不能复。　　凡居家常戒：约内外长幼有不快，即须早道，勿使隐忍以为无苦，过时不知，便为重病，遂成不救。小有不好，即按摩挼捺，令首节通利，泄其邪气。凡人无问有事无事，常须日别蹋脊背四肢一度，头项若令熟蹋，即风气时行，不能侵人。[50p]

    Husbands and wives should not bathe on the same day; it is customary to bathe on the days of the new moon and waning moon, which is auspicious. If one uses water from cooking soup overnight to wash, it can cause skin ailments; washing the face can lead to a loss of luster, and washing the feet can result in pain and sores. Washing the head with hot water and then rinsing with cold can lead to headaches. Drinking water while washing the head can also cause headaches. During times of illness, when one is sweating and recovering, do not wash with cold water, as it can harm the heart and not allow recovery.

    In general, it is advised for those at home to be cautious: if there is any displeasure among family members, they should speak up early and not endure silently, thinking it is a minor issue; if it is left unaddressed, it may worsen into a serious condition. For minor discomforts, gentle massage can help relieve tension and expel pathogenic energy. People should not wait to be asked about matters, and should make it a habit to daily stretch and press the back and limbs once; if the head and neck are well cared for, then seasonal wind and sickness cannot invade a person.[50p]

    此大要妙，不可具论。　　凡人居家及远行，随身常有熟艾一升、备急丸、辟鬼丸，生肌药、甘湿药、丁肿药，水银、大黄、芒硝、甘草、干姜、桂心、蜀椒。不能更蓄余药，此等常不可阙少，及一两卷百一备急药方，并带辟毒蛇蜂蝎等药随身也。　　凡人由觉十日已上康健，即须灸三数穴，以泄风气。每日必须调气补泻，按摩导引为佳。勿以康健便为常，然常须安不忘危。预防诸病也。灸法当须避人神。凡畜手力，细累。春秋皆须与转泻药一度，则不中天行时气也。[51p]

    This essential knowledge is profound and cannot be fully elaborated. For people at home or traveling, they should always carry one sheng of familiar mugwort, emergency pills, and antidote pills, as well as skin-repairing medicine, moistening medicine, and treatments for swelling, along with mercury, rhubarb, Glauber's salt, licorice, dried ginger, cinnamon, and Sichuan pepper. No additional medicines should be stored; these items must not be lacking. One or two rolls of emergency prescriptions should also be carried, along with antidotes for venomous snakes, scorpions, and bees.

    When a person has been healthy for ten days or more, they must perform moxibustion on several acupoints to release wind and regulate qi. Daily adjustments in breathing and practices of massage and guided exercises are ideal. Do not take good health for granted, as one should always remain cautious of danger. This is to prevent various illnesses. Moxibustion must avoid contact with others. One should perform it with careful attention to manual strength and not overstrain. In spring and autumn, one must take purging medicine at least once, to avoid issues caused by seasonal changes.[51p]

    　　　　　服食法

    　　凡人春服小续命汤五剂，及诸补散各一剂；夏大热则服肾沥汤三剂；秋服黄芪等丸一两剂；冬服药酒两三剂，立春日则止。此法终身常尔，则百病不生矣。俗人见浅，但知钩吻之杀人，不信黄精之益寿；但识五谷之疗饥，不知百药之济命；但解施泻以生育，不能闭固以颐养，故有服饵方焉。郄愔曰：夫欲服食，当寻性理所宜，审冷暖之适，不可见彼得力，我便服之。初御药皆先草木，次石，是为将药之大较也。所谓精粗相代，阶粗以至精者也。[52p]

    Dietary Method

    For ordinary people: in spring, take five doses of the small longevity elixir and one dose each of various nourishing powders; in summer, during great heat, take three doses of kidney infusion; in autumn, take one to two doses of pills made from astragalus and similar herbs; in winter, take two to three doses of medicinal wine, but stop on the day of the onset of spring. If this method is followed throughout one’s life, then one will not fall ill. Common people see superficially; they only know the harmful effects of certain poisonous plants but do not believe in the longevity benefits of huangqi (astragalus); they only recognize grains as a remedy for hunger and do not understand the life-saving properties of myriad herbs; they only know how to use purgatives for fertility, but cannot grasp the need for consolidation and nourishment, hence the necessity for using dietary methods. Qi Yi said: When it comes to diet, one should seek what is appropriate according to nature, carefully considering the suitability of cold and heat; one cannot simply follow what seems powerful and take it without discernment. Initially, medicinal herbs should prioritize plants, then stones, establishing the foundational principles of using medicines. This is about alternating the refined and the coarse, graduating from the coarse to the refined.[52p]

    夫人从少至长，体习五谷，卒不可一朝顿遗之。凡服药物，为益迟微，则无充饥之验。然积年不已，方能骨髓填实，五谷居然而自断。今人多望朝夕之效，求目下之应，腑脏未充，便以绝粒，谷气始除，药未有用，又将御女，形神与俗无别，以此致毙，期不怪哉！服习大体，皆有次第。不知其术者，非止反有所损，卒亦不得其力。故服饵大法，必先去三虫；三虫既去，次服草药；好得药力，次服木药；好得力讫，次服石药。依此次第，乃得遂其药性，庶事安稳，可以延龄矣。[53p]

    A person from youth to adulthood cultivates the essence of the five grains and cannot suddenly abandon them. When taking medicine, if the benefits are slow and subtle, it will not satisfy hunger. However, through many years of consistency, one can strengthen their bones and marrow, allowing the grains to naturally become effective. Nowadays, many people expect immediate results and seek quick fixes; when their internal organs are not well-nourished, they abruptly stop eating, diminish the essence of the grains, and the medicine has no effect. They then turn to women, becoming no different from the common folk, leading to their demise—this should not be surprising! The principles of taking medicine must follow a certain order. Those who do not understand this method not only suffer harm but also ultimately fail to gain strength. Therefore, in the proper method of taking medicine, one must first eliminate the three pests; after eliminating the three pests, one can then take herbal medicine; once the medicinal strength is properly absorbed, one can take wood-based medicine; after gaining strength from that, one can then take stone-based medicine. Following this order allows one to fully realize the properties of the medicine, ensuring stability in health and potentially prolonging life.[53p]

    　　　　　黄帝杂忌法

    　　旦起勿开目洗面，令人目濇，失明饶泪。清旦常言善事，勿恶言。闻恶事，即向所来方三唾之，吉。又勿嗔怒，勿叱咤咄呼，勿嗟叹，勿唱奈何，名曰请祸。勿立膝坐而交臂膝上，勿令发覆面，皆不祥。勿举足向火，勿对灶骂詈。凡行立坐勿背日，吉。勿面北坐久思，不祥起。凡欲行来，常存魁罡在头上，所向皆吉。若欲征战，存斗柄在前以指敌，吉。勿面北冠带，凶。勿向西北唾，犯魁罡神，凶。勿咳唾，唾不用远，成肺病，令人手足重，及背痛咳嗽。亦勿向西北大小便。勿杀龟蛇。勿怒目视日月，善令人失明。行及乘马，不用回顾，则神去。人不用鬼行踖粟。[54p]

    Yellow Emperor's Miscellaneous Taboos

    Upon rising in the morning, do not open your eyes to wash your face; this can cause eye irritation, loss of sight, and excessive tearing. In the early morning, speak only good words and avoid wicked speech. If you hear bad news, immediately spit three times towards the direction from which it came, which will be auspicious. Do not become angry, shout, or sigh, nor should you sing lamentations, as these are said to invite misfortune. Do not sit kneeling with your arms crossed over your knees, and do not let your hair cover your face, for both are inauspicious. Do not point your feet at the fire, nor curse at the stove. In all actions of standing or sitting, do not turn your back to the sun; this is auspicious. Do not sit facing north for a long time in contemplation, as it brings misfortune. Whenever you travel, always keep the North Star above your head; this ensures good fortune in all directions. If you intend to go to war, keep a fighting posture aimed at the enemy, which is auspicious. Do not wear a hat facing north, as this is ominous. Do not spit towards the northwest, as it offends the deity of the North Star, also ominous. Do not cough or spit unnecessarily, as this can lead to lung disease, heaviness in the limbs, and back pain. Also, do not urinate or defecate toward the northwest. Do not kill turtles or snakes. Do not glare at the sun or moon, as this is known to cause blindness. When walking or riding a horse, avoid looking back, for it causes the spirit to depart. A person should not travel in a ghostly manner.[54p]

    凡过神庙，慎勿辄入，入必恭敬，不得举目恣意顾瞻，当如对严君焉，乃享其福耳。不尔速获其祸。亦不得返首顾视神庙。忽见龙蛇，勿兴心惊怪，亦勿注意瞻视。忽见鬼怪变异之物即强抑之，勿怪。呪曰：见怪不怪，其怪自坏。又路行及众中，见殊妙美女，慎勿熟视而爱之。此当魑魅之物，使人深爱。无问深山旷野稠人广众之中，皆亦如之。凡山水有沙虱处，勿在中浴，害人；欲渡者，随驴马后急渡，不伤人。有水弩处，射人影即死；欲渡水者，以物打水，其弩即散，急渡不伤。凡诸山有孔穴，入采宝者，惟三月、九月，余月山闭气交，犯，死。凡人空腹，不宜见尸，臭气入鼻，舌上白起，口常臭；欲见尸者，皆须饮酒，见之能辟毒凶。行触热，途中逢河勿洗面，生乌(黑干)。[55p]

    Whenever passing a temple, one must be cautious and not enter carelessly. If one does enter, it must be with respect, and one should not gaze about indiscriminately, as if before a stern lord; then one may partake of its blessings. If not, one will quickly encounter misfortune. One must also not look back at the temple. If one suddenly sees dragons or serpents, do not become agitated or curious, nor pay attention to them. If one unexpectedly sees strange or monstrous beings, suppress any feeling of surprise; do not be alarmed. There is a saying: "To see the strange without surprise will cause the strangeness to fade."

    Furthermore, while traveling or among crowds, if you see extraordinarily beautiful women, be careful not to gaze too intently or fall in love; these may be spirits that lead one to deep infatuation. This applies equally in remote mountains, wilderness, or in crowded areas. In places where sand or leeches are found in water, do not bathe there, as it can be harmful. To cross, follow after donkeys or horses swiftly, as this does not bring harm. Where there are water traps, if one shoots at a person's shadow, they will die; those wishing to cross water should strike the water with an object so that the trap disperses, allowing for a safe crossing.

    In all mountains with holes or cavities, treasure hunters should only enter during the third or ninth months; in other months, the mountains close off their energy, and to trespass will lead to death. Under no circumstances should a person with an empty stomach look upon a corpse, as the foul odor will enter their nostrils, causing a white coating on their tongue and a persistent bad smell. Those who wish to see a corpse must only do so after drinking alcohol, as it helps ward off the poisonous effects. When encountering heat while traveling, do not wash your face in the river, as it will lead to darkening of the skin.[55p]

    　　　　河间六书 【金　刘完素】

    　　　　　摄生论

    　　《内经》谓法于阴阳，和于术数，饮食有节，起居有常，不妄作劳，故能形与神俱，而尽终其天年，度百岁乃去。今时之人不然也，以酒为浆，以妄为常，醉以入房，以欲竭其精，以耗散其真，不知持满，不时御神，务快其心，逆于生乐，起居无节，故半百而衰也。夫饮食起居，乃人生日用之法，纵恣不能知节，而欲传精神服天气者，不亦难乎？又经曰：饮食自倍，肠胃乃伤。起居如惊，神气乃浮。是以圣人春木旺，以膏香助胃；夏火旺，以膏腥助肺。金用事，膳膏臊以助肝；水用事，膳膏膻以助心。所谓因其不胜而助之也。故食饮之常，保其生之要者，五谷、五果、五畜、五菜也，脾胃待此而食廪备，三焦待此而道路通，荣卫待此以清以浊，筋骨待此以柔以正。故经云：盖五味相济，斯无五宫之伤，所以养其形也。[56p]

    Discussion on Maintaining Life

    The "Internal Canon" states that one should follow the principles of yin and yang, harmonize with techniques and numbers, moderate eating and drinking, and maintain a regular schedule. Avoid excessive labor so that body and spirit remain together, allowing one to live to the end of their allotted years, departing only after a hundred. However, modern people are different; they consider wine as their staple, treat fantasies as reality, enter rooms intoxicated, deplete their essence through desire, and squander their true nature. They do not understand moderation, fail to manage their spirit in a timely manner, strive for momentary pleasure, and live without a schedule, resulting in decline by middle age.

    Diet and daily routines are fundamental to a person's life practice. It is indeed difficult to want to maintain vitality and harmony with nature while indulging in excess and lacking moderation. The text also states: when food intake is excessive, it harms the intestines and stomach; a disturbed daily routine leads to a restless mind.

    Therefore, sages align with the seasons—spring brings vitality, assisted by fragrant oils for the stomach; summer's fire thrives, aided by aromatic meats for the lungs. In autumn, one should consume oils and pungent foods to support the liver; during winter, warming foods should be consumed to nourish the heart. This is to assist that which is weakened.

    Thus, the regularity of food and drink is essential for sustaining life. The key components are the five grains, five fruits, five animals, and five vegetables. The spleen and stomach rely on these for nourishment, the three burners require them for smooth passage, the channels of energy depend on them for clarity and impurity, and the bones and muscles need them for flexibility and strength. Therefore, the text concludes: the harmony of the five flavors prevents damage to the five organs, which is crucial for nourishing the body.[56p]

    虽五味为之养形，若味过于酸，肝气以津，脾气乃绝；味过于咸，大骨气劳短肌，心气抑；味过于甘，心气喘满色黑，肾气不衡；味过于苦，脾气不濡，胃气乃厚；味过于辛，筋脉沮弛，精神乃央。所谓失五味之常而损其形也。王注曰：味有偏胜，脏有偏绝。此之谓也。饮食者养其形，起居者调其神。[57p]

    Although the five flavors nourish the body, if the flavor is too sour, it affects the liver's energy and the spleen's energy will be depleted; if the flavor is too salty, it exhausts the bones and muscles, and depresses the heart's energy; if the flavor is too sweet, it causes the heart to become congested, leading to a dark complexion and imbalanced kidney energy; if the flavor is too bitter, it dries out the spleen's energy and thickens the stomach's energy; if the flavor is too pungent, it weakens the tendons, and the spirit becomes weak. This is what is meant by losing the proper balance of the five flavors and damaging the body. Wang's commentary says: flavors can have excessive strengths, and organs can have excessive weaknesses. This is what it refers to. Diet nourishes the body, while daily activities regulate the spirit.[57p]

    是以圣人春三月夜卧早起，被发缓形，见于发陈之时，且曰以使志生；夏三月夜卧早起，无厌于日，见于蕃秀之时，且曰使志无怒，使气得泄；秋三月早卧早起，与鸡俱兴，见于容平之时，收敛神气，且曰使志安宁，以应秋气；冬三月早卧晚起，去寒就温，见于闭藏之时，且曰使志若伏若匿，若有私意，若己有得。此顺生长收藏之道。春夏养阳，秋冬养阴，顺四时起居法，所以调其神也。经所谓逆春气则少阳不生，肝气内变；逆夏气则太阳不长，心气内洞；逆秋气则太阴不收，肺气焦满；逆冬气则少阴不藏，肾气独沉。此失四时之气，所以伤其神也。智者顺四时，不逆阴阳之道，而不失五味损益之理，故形与神俱久矣，乃尽其天年而去。与夫务快其心，逆于生乐者，何足与语此道哉！故圣人行之，贤者佩之，岂虚语哉！[58p]

    Therefore, the sage sleeps at night in early spring and rises early, allowing his hair to flow freely, observing the time of the hair's growth, and says this fosters vitality. In early summer, he again sleeps at night and rises early, not being weary of the sun, observing the flourishing time, and says this allows the mind to remain tranquil and the energy to diffuse. In early autumn, he sleeps early and rises early, waking with the rooster, observing the time of harmonious balance, gathering his spirit and energy, and says this brings peace to the mind, in response to the autumn atmosphere. In early winter, he sleeps early and rises late, moving away from the cold towards warmth, observing the time of closing and storing, and says this keeps the mind concealed, as if having private intentions or personal gains. This follows the path of growth, storage, and conservation. In spring and summer, one nourishes the yang, while in autumn and winter, one nourishes the yin. By following the natural rhythms of the four seasons in daily life, one adjusts their spirit. The classics state that going against the spring energies leads to a deficiency in yang, causing liver energies to stagnate; going against the summer energies causes a deficiency in yang, leading to disturbances in heart energy; going against the autumn energies results in failing to gather yin, causing lung energies to become overwhelmed; going against the winter energies fails to preserve yin, causing kidney energies to plunge. This neglect of the seasonal energies damages the spirit. The wise follow the rhythms of the four seasons, not contradicting the principles of yin and yang, and do not lose the harmonious balance of the five flavors. Thus, both body and spirit endure for a long time, allowing them to fully spend their allotted years. Those who hasten their hearts and go against the joy of living have no need to discuss this path! Therefore, the sage practices this, the wise cherish it; is it not profound wisdom?[58p]

    　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】

    　　　　　安养心神调治脾胃论

    　　灵兰秘典论曰：心者君主之官，神明出焉。凡喜怒忿悲忧思恐惧，皆损元气。夫阴火之炽盛，由心生凝滞，七情不安故也。心者神之舍，心君不守，化而为火。夫火者，七神之贼也，故曰阴火大盛，经营之气，不能颐养于神，乃脉病也。神无所养，津液不行，不能生血脉也。人心之神，真气之别名也，得血则生，血生则脉旺。脉者神之舍，若心生凝滞，七神离形，而脉中惟有火矣。善治斯病者，惟在调和脾胃，使心无凝滞，或生欢欣，或逢喜事，或天气暄和，居温和处，或食滋味，或见可欲事，则慧然如无病矣，盖胃中元气得舒伸故也。[59p]

    An Essay on Nourishing the Heart and Regulating the Spleen and Stomach

    The secret texts state: The heart is the ruler's office, from which the spirit emerges. All emotions such as joy, anger, vexation, sorrow, worry, thought, fear, and dread deplete vital energy. The excessive fire of yin arises from the heart's stagnation, which is due to the instability of the seven emotions. The heart is the dwelling of the spirit; if the lord of the heart does not guard it, it transforms into fire. Fire is the thief of the seven spirits, hence it is said that excessive yin fire disrupts the nourishing energy of the spirit, leading to pulse disorders. When the spirit is un-nourished, the fluids do not circulate, thus blood vessels cannot generate blood. The spirit of the human heart is also known as true energy; it thrives on blood, and when blood flourishes, the pulse becomes vigorous. The pulse is the dwelling of the spirit; if the heart suffers stagnation, the seven spirits will deviate, and the pulse will contain only fire. To effectively treat this condition, one must harmonize the spleen and stomach, allowing the heart to be free of stagnation. Whether through experiencing joy, favorable events, gentler weather, residing in a moderate environment, enjoying delicious food, or encountering desirable sights, one can feel as if there is no ailment, due to the relaxation of vital energy in the stomach.[59p]

    　　　　　脾胃将理法

    　　或方怒不可食。不可太饱太饥。饮食欲相接而温和，宜谷食多而肉食少，不宜食肉汁。忌寒湿物，令肌肉不生。阳气潜伏，四肢怠惰之证，疼痛沉重，时当湿雨，则泄利大便后，有白脓血痢，或肠澼下血病。此乃诸阳气不行阳道之故也。　　劳则阳气衰，宜乘车马游玩，遇风寒则止。　　行住坐卧，各得其宜，不可至疲倦。　　日晴暧，可以温汤澡浴。勿以热汤，令汗大出。　　勿困中饮食，虽饥渴当先卧，至不困乃饮食，食后少动作。　　忌博奕劳心。[60p]

    Regulation of the Spleen and Stomach

    One should avoid eating when angry. It is not advisable to be too full or too hungry. Meals should be well-balanced and warm, with a preference for grains over meat, and it's best to avoid meat juices. Cold and damp foods should be avoided as they hinder the growth of muscle. The yang energy may become dormant, leading to fatigue and pain in the limbs; during rainy weather, this can result in diarrhea and dysentery with white pus and blood, or bloody diarrhea disease. This is due to the stagnation of yang energy not flowing properly.

    Excessive exertion weakens yang energy, so leisure activities like riding or traveling are encouraged; however, one should rest if faced with wind or cold. Proper balance in movement and rest is essential; one should not become overly fatigued. On sunny, warm days, warm baths are beneficial, but do not use excessively hot water that induces heavy sweating.

    Avoid eating or drinking in a state of exhaustion; even if hungry or thirsty, one should rest first. Only eat or drink when feeling adequately rested, and limit activity after eating. Additionally, avoid mental strain from gambling.[60p]

    遇夜汗出，宜避贼风。　　夜半，收心静坐少时，此生发周身血气之大要也。　　夜寝语言，大损元气。须默默少时，候周身阳气行，方可言语。　　忌浴当风，汗当风。须以手摩汗孔合，方许见风，必无中风中寒之疾。　　遇卒风暴寒，衣服不能御者，则宜挣努周身之气以当之。气弱不能御而受之者，病。　　远行卒遇疫疠之气，饮酒者不病，腹中有食者病，空腹者死。　　白粥，粳米、菉豆、小豆、盐豉皆渗利小便，且小便数不可更利，况大泻阳气，反行阴道？切禁湿面，如食之觉快，勿禁。[61p]

    When encountering night sweats, one should avoid drafty winds. At midnight, one should gather the mind and sit quietly for a while; this is crucial for promoting the blood and vital energy throughout the body. Speaking after midnight greatly depletes vitality. One must remain silent for a while, waiting for the Yang energy to circulate in the body, before speaking.

    Avoid bathing in the wind and letting sweat come into contact with it. It is necessary to rub the sweat pores together with hands before exposing oneself to the wind, ensuring there are no illnesses from wind or cold. If one unexpectedly encounters fierce cold winds and the clothing cannot provide warmth, one should vigorously activate the body's energy to defend against it. If the energy is weak and cannot resist, illness will follow.

    When traveling and suddenly encountering epidemic conditions, those who drink alcohol do not fall ill, whereas those with food in their stomachs may become sick, and those who are empty-stomached may die.

    White porridge, made from glutinous rice, mung beans, adzuki beans, and salted soybeans, promotes urination and should not be excessively diuretic. Furthermore, excessive diarrhea can deplete Yang energy and affect the Yin pathways negatively. One must avoid damp food; if it brings comfort upon eating, do not restrict it.[61p]

    　　药中不可服泽泻、茯苓、猪苓、灯心、琥珀、通草、木通、滑石之类，皆泻阳道行阴道也。如渴小便不利，或闭塞不通，则服；得利勿再服。　　忌大咸助火邪而泻肾水真阴，及大辛味、蒜韭、五辣、酢、大料物、官桂、干姜之类，皆伤元气。　　如衣薄而气短则添衣，于无风处居处。如气尚短，则用沸汤一碗熏其口鼻，即不短也。　　如衣厚而气短，则宜减衣，摩汗孔令合，于无风处居止。　　如久居高屋，或天寒阴湿所遏，令气短者，亦如前法熏之。[62p]

    In terms of medicine, one should avoid taking ingredients such as Alisma, Poria, Polyporus, lampwick, amber, bamboo pith, Akebia, and talc, as they all promote downward movement in the Yang channels and inhibit the Yin. If experiencing thirst with difficult urination or blockage, these can be taken; but if relieved, do not take again.

    Avoid excessive salt as it enhances fire evil and depletes the true Yin of the kidney, as well as strong flavors, garlic, leeks, pungent spices, vinegar, star anise, cinnamon, and dried ginger, all of which harm the vital energy.

    If wearing thin clothes and feeling short of breath, add more layers and find shelter from the wind. If still short of breath, one can inhale steam from a bowl of boiling soup; this will relieve the shortness.

    Conversely, if dressed in heavy clothing and feeling short of breath, it is advisable to remove some layers and stimulate the sweat pores, while staying out of the wind.

    If one has been in a high building for a long time or is hindered by cold and damp weather, causing shortness of breath, one should also use the aforementioned steaming method.[62p]

    　　如居周密小室，或大热而处寒凉气短者，则出就风日。凡气短，皆宜食滋味汤饮，令胃调和。　　或大热能食而渴喜寒饮，当从权以饮之，然不可耽嗜。如冬喜热饮，亦依时暂饮。　　夜不安寝，衾厚热壅故也，当急去之，仍拭汗孔。或薄而寒，即加之，睡自稳也。　　饥而睡不安，则宜少食；食饱而睡不安，则宜少行坐。遇天气变更，风寒阴晦，宜预避之。大抵宜温暖，避风寒，省言语，少劳役为上。　　若服升浮之药，先一日将理，次日腹空，方服。服毕，更将理十日，先三日尤甚，不然则反害也。[63p]

    If you are in a small, tightly enclosed space and are feeling hot but experiencing cold and shortness of breath, then go out into the wind and sunlight. For any shortness of breath, it is advisable to consume nourishing soups and drinks to help harmonize the stomach.

    If you feel hot and have a desire for cold drinks, you should drink moderately, but do not indulge excessively. Similarly, if you prefer hot drinks in winter, you should only consume them as appropriate for the season.

    If you cannot sleep well at night due to heavy and warm bedding, you should promptly remove it and wipe away any sweat. If it is too thin and cold, add more bedding, and you will sleep more soundly.
