    If you feel hungry but cannot sleep well, it is better to eat lightly; if you are too full and cannot sleep well, it is advisable to limit your activities and sitting. When the weather changes suddenly, with wind, cold, and overcast skies, it is wise to take precautions. Generally, it is best to stay warm, avoid wind and cold, speak less, and engage in minimal labor.

    If you are taking lifting and floating medicines, first prepare for a day, then take them on an empty stomach the next day. After taking them, continue to maintain regimen for ten days, with special care during the first three days, otherwise, it may cause adverse effects.[63p]

    　　　　　远欲论

    　　名与身孰亲？身与货孰多？以隋侯之珠，弹千仞之雀，世必笑之，何取之轻而弃之重耶？残躯六十有五，耳目半失于视听，百脉沸腾而烦心，身如众派漂流，瞑目则魂如浪去，神气衰于前日，饮食减于曩时，但应人事，病皆弥甚，以己之所有，岂止隋侯之珠哉！安于淡薄，少思寡欲，省语以养气，不妄作劳以养形，虚心以维神，寿夭得失，安之于数，得丧既轻，血气自然谐和，邪无所容，病安增剧？苟能持此，亦庶几于道，可谓得其真趣矣。
    　　　　　省言箴

    　　气乃神之祖，精乃气之子。气者，精神之根蒂也。大矣哉！积气以成精，积精以全神。必清必静，御之以道，可以为天人。有道者能之，予何人哉？切宜省言而已。[64p]

    Discussion on Distant Desires

    Which is closer, name or body? Which is greater, body or wealth? If the beads of the Duke of Sui are used to strike sparrows soaring thousands of feet, the world will surely laugh. Why take the light and discard the heavy? At sixty-five, my frail body has lost half of its ability to see and hear, my blood vessels are agitated and my mind is troubled. My body drifts like debris, and when my eyes close, my spirit seems to drift away like a wave. My vitality is weaker than before, and my appetite has decreased from what it used to be. I merely respond to human affairs, and my ailments only worsen. Is what I possess any less than the Duke of Sui’s pearls? I find peace in simplicity, think less and desire little, speak sparingly to nurture my spirit, refrain from engaging in vain labor to sustain my form, keep an open heart to maintain my spirit. Whether longevity or early death, I accept it all as fate; gains and losses are trivial. When blood and energies are naturally balanced, there is no room for ill, and how can ailments worsen? If I can hold onto this, I might approach the Dao, and can be said to have grasped its true essence.

    Sayings of Reflection

    Qi is the ancestor of spirit; essence is the offspring of qi. Qi is the root of spirit. How grand it is! Accumulate qi to form essence, accumulate essence to perfect spirit. It must be pure and tranquil; guided by the Dao, one can become like heaven and man. Those who possess the Dao can achieve this; what about me? It is best to simply reflect and speak less.[64p]

    　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】

    　　　　　不治已病治未病

    　　与其救疗于有疾之后，不若摄养于无疾之先。盖疾成而后药者，徒劳而已。是故已病而不治，所以为医家之戒；未病而先治，以明摄生之理。夫如是则思患而预防之者，何患之有哉？此圣人不治已病，治未病之意也。尝谓备土以防水也，苟不以闭塞其涓涓之流则滔天之势不能遏；备水以防火也，若不以扑灭其荧荧之光则燎原之焰不能止。其水火既盛，尚不能止遏，况病之已成，岂能治欤？故宜夜卧早起于发陈之春，早起夜卧于蕃秀之夏，以缓其形，无怒而遂其志，以之食凉食寒而养其阳，圣人春夏治未病者如此。与鸡俱兴，于容平之秋，必待于日光闭藏之冬，以敛神匿志而私其意，以之食温食热而养其阴，圣人秋冬治未病者如此。[65p]

    Danxi Heart Method (Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng)

    Treating the Unmanifested Illness Rather than the Manifested One

    It is better to nurture health before illness arises than to treat a condition once it has developed. Once the sickness has taken hold and medicine is applied, it is usually in vain. Therefore, not treating existing illnesses serves as a caution for physicians; treating before the onset of illness elucidates the principles of health preservation. Thus, if one considers potential problems and takes preventive measures, what worries could there be? This encapsulates the wise approach of not treating existing ailments but addressing the potential for illness.

    For instance, preparing soil to prevent water: if one does not block its flowing streams, a surging flood cannot be contained. Preparing water to combat fire: if one does not extinguish its flickering flames, the wildfire cannot be stopped. If even the overflowing water or raging fire cannot be tamed, how can one expect to treat an already established illness? Therefore, it is advisable to sleep early and rise with the dawn in the spring, and to rise early and sleep late in the summer, allowing the body to remain relaxed, avoiding anger and fulfilling one's intentions, providing cool and cold food to nourish one's Yang. This is how the wise treat the unmanifested illness in spring and summer. In the autumn, one should rise with the chickens and await the hidden sun in winter to conserve one’s spirit and harbor one’s intentions, providing warm and heated food to nourish one’s Yin. This is how the wise treat the unmanifested illness in autumn and winter.[65p]

    或曰见肝之病，先实其脾脏之虚，则木邪不能传；见右颊之赤，先泻其肺经之热，则金邪不能盛，此乃治未病之法。今以顺四时调养神志而为治未病者，是何意邪？盖保身长全者，所以为圣人之道；治病十全者，所以为上工。不治已病治未病之说，着于四气调神大论，厥有旨哉！昔黄帝与天师难疑答问之书，未尝不以摄养为先，始论乎天真，次论乎调神。既已法于阴阳，而继之以调于四气；既曰食饮有节，而又继之以起居有常。谆谆然以养生为急务者，意欲治未然之病，无使至于已病难图也。厥后秦缓达乎此，见晋侯病在膏肓，语之曰：不可为也！扁鹊明乎此，视齐侯病至骨髓，断之曰：不可救也！噫惜齐晋诸侯不知治未病之理？
    　　　　格致余论 【元　朱震亨】
    [66p]

    Some say that when one observes disease of the liver, one must first address the weakness of the spleen; only then can the wood pathogen be prevented from spreading. When one sees redness in the right cheek, one must first purge the heat from the lung channels; only then can the metal pathogen be restrained. This is indeed the method of treating illness before it arises.

    Now, to cultivate the spirit in accordance with the four seasons to prevent illness—what does this mean? It is the way of the sage to preserve life; it is the mark of the superior craftsman to treat illness thoroughly. The idea of treating the unmanifested disease before it manifests is elaborated in the "Treatise on the Harmonization of the Four Qi." How insightful it is!

    In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor and the Celestial Master exchanged questions and answers, always prioritizing cultivation and care. They first discussed the nature of heaven, followed by the harmonization of the spirit. Once aligned with yin and yang, they then emphasized the adjustment to the four qi. They spoke of moderation in food and drink, and also emphasized consistency in daily routines. The earnest emphasis on nurturing life is intended to address potential ailments before they develop into serious conditions.

    Later, Qin observed a noble from Jin with a disease in the diaphragm and advised, “It is beyond remedy!” Bian Que, understanding this principle, viewed the Duke of Qi's affliction as reaching the very marrow and declared, “It is beyond saving!” Alas, how unfortunate that the lords of Qi and Jin failed to grasp the principles of preventing illnesses before they manifest?[66p]

    　　　　　饮食箴

    　　人身之贵，父母遗体。为口伤身，滔滔皆是。人有此身，饥渴随兴。乃作饮食，以遂其生。眷彼昧者，因纵口味。五味之过，疾病蜂起。病之生也，其机甚微。馋涎所牵，忽而不思。病之成也，饮食俱废。忧贻父母，医祷百计。山野贫贱，淡薄是谙。动作不衰，此身亦安。均气同体，我独多病。悔悟一萌，尘开镜净。曰节饮食，易之象辞。养小失大，孟子所讥。口能致病，亦败尔德。守口如瓶，服之无斁。
    　　　　　色欲箴

    　　惟人之生，与天地参。坤道成女，干道成男。配为夫妇，生育攸寄。血气方刚，惟其时矣。成之以礼，接之以时。父子之亲，其要在兹。隧彼昧者，徇纵情欲。惟恐不及，济以燥毒。气阳血阴，人身之神。阴平阳秘，我体长春。血气几何，而不自惜？我之所生，翻为我贼。女之耽兮，其欲实多。闺房之肃，门庭之和。士之耽兮，其家自废。既丧厥德，此身亦瘁。远彼帷幕，放心乃收。饮食甘美，身安病瘳。[67p]

    Aptitudes on Food and Drink

    The value of the human body lies in the physical form bestowed by parents. Damaging the body for the sake of the mouth is rampant. While possessing this body, hunger and thirst arise based on desires. Thus, one engages in eating and drinking to sustain life. Those who indulge are often ignorant, leading to a lack of restraint in taste. Excess in flavors brings forth diseases. The emergence of illness is subtle and difficult to detect. Under the pull of gluttony, one suddenly loses focus. When illness becomes established, both food and drink are abandoned. This brings worry to parents, and despite numerous remedies, healing remains a struggle. In poverty and isolation, simplicity is well understood. If action remains unwavering, the body can also remain healthy. When air and essence are balanced, I alone suffer from ailments. Upon the awakening of regret, dust clears and the mirror is purified. It emphasizes moderation in eating and drinking, easy to say but hard to practice. Nurturing trivial matters can lead to grave losses, as Mencius remarked. The mouth can cause illness and also undermine virtue. Guarding one's mouth like a sealed bottle ensures there is no disarray.

    Aptitudes on Desire

    The essence of human life is intertwined with heaven and earth. The feminine principle emerges from the earth, while the masculine form arises from heaven. Together they become husband and wife, with reproduction as their purpose. In youth, blood and qi are vigorous; this is the prime of life. Formality governs the relationship, and timing is essential. The bond between parent and child hinges on this understanding. Yet, those who are ignorant indulge in lust without restraint. Fearing they may miss out, they are further driven by impulsive desires. Qi corresponds to yang and blood corresponds to yin – they are the spirit of the human body. When yin is balanced with secretive yang, my body embraces eternal spring. How can there be ample blood and qi without self-cultivation? What was meant for my sustenance becomes my downfall. Women in their indulgence possess many desires. In the serenity of the boudoir and harmony of the household, they flourish. Men in their indulgence, however, may bring ruin to their homes. Having lost their virtue, their bodies also wither. It is essential to distance oneself from temptation; only then can the mind find peace. When food and drink are delightful, the body thrives and illness recedes.[67p]

    　　　　　茹淡论

    　　或问《内经》谓精不足者补之以味，又曰地食人以五味。古者年五十食肉，子今年迈七十矣，尽却盐酰，岂中道乎？何子之神茂而色泽也？曰：味有出于天赋者，有成于人为者。天之所赋者，若谷菽菜果，自然冲和之味，有养人补阴之功，此《内经》所谓味也。人之所为者，皆烹饪调和偏厚之味，有致疾伐命之毒，此吾子所疑之味也。今盐酰之却，非真茹淡者。大麦与粟之咸，粳米、山药之甘，葱薤之辛之类，皆味也，子以为淡乎？安于冲和之味者，心之收，火之降也；以偏厚之味为安者，欲之纵，火之盛也。何疑之有？《内经》又曰：阴之所生，本在五味。非天赋之味乎？阴之五官，伤在五味。非人为之味乎？圣人防民之具，于是为备。凡人饥则必食。彼粳米甘而淡者，土之德也，物之属阴而最补者也，惟可与菜同进。[68p]

    Discourse on Eating Light Foods

    Someone asked: The Inner Canon states that if essence is insufficient, it should be supplemented with flavor, and also mentions that the earth feeds people with the five flavors. In ancient times, at fifty, people consumed meat; now, at seventy, my son completely abstains from salt. Is this not taking the middle path? Why does my son possess such vitality and complexion?

    He answered: There are flavors bestowed by heaven and those cultivated by man. The flavors bestowed by heaven, such as grains, legumes, vegetables, and fruits, have a naturally harmonious taste and the ability to nourish and replenish the yin, which is what the Inner Canon refers to as flavor. The flavors cultivated by humans are mostly overly rich and heavily seasoned, which can be harmful and detrimental to one's life—this is the flavor you doubt.

    Now, to refuse salt and strong seasonings is not truly to eat lightly. The salty taste of barley and millet, the sweetness of glutinous rice and yam, the pungent flavors of scallion and garlic, are all flavors. Do you consider them to be light? Those who are content with natural flavors have tranquility in their heart and a cooling of their fire; those who find security in rich flavors pursue excessive desires and have an overactive fire. What is there to doubt?

    The Inner Canon also states: The yin emerges primarily from the five flavors. Are these not heavenly bestowed flavors? The five organs of the yin suffer from the five flavors. Are these not human-made flavors? The sages made provisions to guard against these things. When a person is hungry, they must eat. The glutinous rice, which is sweet yet light, embodies the virtues of the earth, and being fundamentally related to yin, is the most nourishing; it should only be consumed alongside vegetables.[68p]

    经以菜为充者，恐于饥时顿食，或虑过多，因致胃损，故以菜助其充足，取其疏通而易化，此天地生物之仁也。《论语》曰：肉虽多，不使胜食气。传曰：宾主百拜而酒三行，以避酒祸。此圣人施教之意也。盖谷与肥鲜同进，厚味得谷为助，其积之也久，宁不助阴火而致毒乎？故服食家在却谷者则可，不却谷而服食，未有不被其毒者。《内经》谓久而增气，物化之常；气增而久，夭之由也。彼安于厚味者，未之思耳。或又问精不足者补之以味，何不言补气？曰：味，阴也；气，阳也。补精以阴，求其本也，故补之以味。若甘草、白朮、地黄、泽泻、五味子、天门冬之类，皆味之厚者也。经曰虚者补之，正此意也。上文谓形不足者温之以气。夫为劳倦所伤，气之虚，故不足。温者养也，温存以养，使气自充，气充则形完矣，故言温而不言补。经曰劳者温之，正此意也。彼为《局方》者，不知出此，凡诸虚损证，悉以温热佐辅补药，名之曰温补，不能求经旨者也。[69p]

    Those who use vegetables as sustenance may, in times of hunger, suddenly overindulge or worry about overeating, which may lead to stomach damage. Therefore, vegetables assist in nourishment, facilitating digestion and ease—this is the benevolence of nature. The Analects say: “Though meat is plentiful, it should not overpower the spirit of eating.” The commentary mentions: “With host and guest bowing a hundred times and three rounds of wine, one avoids the perils of wine.” This reflects the teachings of the sages. Indeed, grains and rich meats are best consumed together. When one accumulates rich flavors without grains over time, do they not assist the inner fire and create toxicity? Therefore, those who eat while avoiding grains can do so, but those who do not avoid grains while eating will inevitably succumb to their toxicity. The Inner Canon states that prolonged illness depletes vital energy, which is the norm of transformation; when energy increases over time, it leads to premature death. Those who are accustomed to rich flavors seldom reflect on this. If one asks why flavor compensates for insufficient essence rather than saying it replenishes energy, the reply is: flavor represents yin; energy represents yang. To replenish essence is to seek its root, hence it is supplemented with flavor. Herbs like licorice, white atractylodes, rehmannia, alisma, schisandra, and asparagine are all rich in flavor. The scripture states, “Supplement the deficient,” which aligns with this understanding. The previous text suggests that when the body is deficient, it is invigorated with energy. Exhaustion causes depletion of energy, hence deficiency. Warming is nurturing; it preserves life and allows energy to replenish. When energy is abundant, the body is complete. Thus, it speaks of warmth without mentioning supplementation. The scripture states, “Those who are fatigued should be warmed,” which is precisely this intention. Those who follow the “Classical Formulas” do not realize this; all signs of deficiency are treated with warming and supplementary herbs, termed “warming supplementation,” yet they fail to grasp the true meaning of the scriptures.[69p]

    　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

    　　　　　保养说[70p]

    Medical Introduction by Li Chan (Ming Dynasty)

    Discussion on Health Maintenance[70p]

    　　医家既知修德，又当爱惜自己精神，医之难者，难于此也。倘精神昏耗，察识必不能精，方药必不能当，虽有济人之心而势不能及也。若夫病有服药针灸不效者，以其不知保养之方。古云：举其病后善服药，莫若病前善自防。　　按丹溪茹淡、阴火二篇，病者当时目之。或者议其茹淡之偏，殊不知其本意为痰火阴虚之人作也。人至中年，肾气日衰，加之佚欲，便成虚损。兴阳补剂服之，则潮热不胜。专服滋降之药，虽暂得清爽，久则中气愈虚，血无生化。所以只得于饮食上调节，戒一切煎炒、炙煿、酒酢、糟酱、燥热之物，恐燥血也；戒一切生冷时果，时菜，恐伤脾也。能甘淡薄，则五味之本，自足以补五脏。养老慈幼皆然。其酒肉补阳助火，内伤劳倦，元气虚者，虽病，所禁忌之物，亦可暂食益胃，东垣有是言也。但节饮食极难，非惟酒肉，必以礼义樽节而不可过，虽饭粥亦不可饱，恒言吃得三碗只吃两碗。《论语》云：肉虽多，不使胜食气。[71p]

    The physician must cultivate virtue and cherish one's own spirit; this is where the difficulty in healing lies. If the spirit is depleted, perception will be impaired, and the appropriate medicine cannot be administered; even with a heart to help others, one's strength will be insufficient. If a patient finds that medicine or acupuncture is ineffective, it is usually because they do not know how to preserve their health. As the ancients said, "It is better to protect oneself before falling ill than to take medicine after becoming sick."

    According to Danxi, the works on nourishing the mind and calming the fire, one should observe the condition of the sick person at that time. Some may debate the preference for gentle nourishment, but they overlook that its true intention is for those with phlegm, fire, and yin deficiency. When a person reaches middle age, kidney energy diminishes day by day, and with indulgence in desires, they become weak. Taking Yang-replenishing tonics may lead to overwhelming heat. While temporarily consuming nourishing descent drugs may provide a sense of refreshment, over time they can worsen one's vitality and blood. Therefore, one must adjust their diet, avoiding all fried, roasted, alcoholic, vinegar, fermented, and dry heat-inducing foods to prevent drying out the blood; also, avoiding all icy fruits and seasonal vegetables to protect the spleen.

    If one can consume mild and light food, the foundation of the five flavors will sufficiently replenish the five organs. This applies to caring for the elderly and nurturing the young. Consumption of meat and alcohol can bolster yang and stoke fire, causing internal injury and exhaustion. Those with weak vital energy, even if ill, should temporarily consume such foods to benefit the stomach, as noted by Dongyuan. However, moderation in diet is extremely difficult; not only meat and alcohol, but also etiquette and restraint must not be overstretched. Even rice and porridge should not be consumed to saturation; there’s a saying, “If you can eat three bowls, only eat two." Confucius stated, “Even with an abundance of meat, do not let it overpower your appetite."[71p]

    小注云：肉气胜，滞谷气；谷气胜，滞元气。元气流行者寿，元气滞者夭。惟酒无量不及乱，在圣人则可，常人当不自有其量而后可不乱也。节色非惟眼招口挑，纵欲宣淫，乱匹配之常经，反交感之正理，得罪天地鬼神。虽自己妻妾，亦不可以妄合。大风、大雨、大热、大寒，朔望本生之期，切宜禁忌。惟静中养见端倪，自然变易其心。一切秽亵之事，且厌之矣，况肯贪恋以丧家珍哉！　　或问保养修养，何以异？曰：无大异也。[72p]

    A brief note states: If the fleshly desires dominate, they obstruct the vital energy; if the vital energy dominates, it obstructs the original Qi. Those whose vital energy flows will have longevity, while those whose vital energy is stagnant will die young. Only wine in moderation does not lead to chaos; for the sage, it is acceptable, but common people should first know their limits to avoid disorder. Restraint in desires is not just about what is visually appealing or physically alluring; indulging in excess disrupts proper relationships and contradicts fundamental principles, offending the heavens, earth, and spirits. Even with one's own wife or concubines, one should not engage in reckless unions. Great winds, heavy rains, extreme heat, and severe cold, especially during the new and full moons, should be approached with caution and restraint. Only in stillness can one nurture insights and naturally alter one's heart. All vile and lewd acts should be abhorred, let alone one who would greedily covet and lose precious family treasures! When asked about nurturing and self-cultivation, the response is: there is not much distinction between them.[72p]

    但修养涉于方外元远，而非恒言恒道；保养不外日用食息，而为人所易知易行。然则修养非欤？曰：据方书，神农起医药之方，黄帝创导引之术，后世传之，失其真尔。《素问》曰：饮食有节，起居有常，不妄作劳，精神内守，病安从来？故能尽其天年，度百岁乃去。此保养之正宗也。盖有节有常而不劳，则气从轨而无俟于搬运之烦，如今之动功也。　　 【内动运任督者，久则生痈；运脾土者，久则腹胀；运丹田者，久则尿血；运项门者，久则脑泄。[73p]

    The cultivation of the self pertains to distant realms beyond ordinary speech and doctrine; maintenance, on the other hand, is about the daily use of food and rest, which is easily understood and practiced by people. Thus, is there no cultivation? It is said: According to ancient texts, Shennong established the methods of medicine, and the Yellow Emperor initiated the techniques of guidance, which were passed down through generations, losing their true essence. The "Suwen" states: Eating and drinking in moderation, maintaining regular habits, avoiding excessive labor, and keeping one's spirit internal—how can illness arise from this? Therefore, one can live out their natural lifespan and depart at the age of a hundred. This is the true doctrine of maintenance. Having moderation and regularity without labor means that vital energy flows in accordance with its natural course, without the need for the burdensome efforts seen in contemporary practices. As for the internal manipulation of the Ren and Du meridians, prolonged practice can lead to carbuncles; prolonged manipulation of the Spleen can cause abdominal distension; prolonged manipulation of the Dan Tian can lead to hematuria; and prolonged manipulation of the cervical region can result in cerebral leakage.[73p]

    内动固不宜矣，至于六字诀，虽能发散外邪而中虚有汗者忌；八段锦，虽能流动气血，而中虚有火者忌。惟《医林集要》所载古导引法，间有一二明显可行者，附录于后，究而言之，亦不过吾儒舞蹈意也。】　　精神内守，则身心凝定，而无侯于制伏之强，如今之静功也。　　 【《丹书》朱砂、铅汞龙虎之说，俱是借喻身心。惟心息相依之说，最为直截明显。心主乎息，息依乎心。心息相住，则精气神满而病却矣。】　　尽天年度百岁乃去，则自古有生必有死，惟不自速其死尔。乌有如今之所谓飞升超脱住世之说耶？或曰：保养既若是之易且显，何今之夭者多而寿者少耶？曰：饮食起居动作之间，安能一一由心所主而无所诖误哉？香醪美味陈于前，虽病所忌也而弗顾情，况意兴动于中，虽病且危也而难遏，贪名竞利之心急，过于劳伤而不觉，此古今之寿相远者，非气禀之异也，实今人之不如古人重其身尔。[74p]

    Internal movement is indeed inappropriate; as for the six-character mantra, though it can disperse external pathogens, those who are internally deficient and have sweat should avoid it; the eight-piece brocade, while capable of moving qi and blood, should be avoided by those who are internally deficient and have fire. Only a few practices of ancient guided movement recorded in the "Essentials of Medical Forest" are clearly feasible, and these are summarized below. Ultimately, they are simply the dances of scholars.

    When the spirit is inwardly preserved, the body and mind become stable, and there is no reliance on strong subjugation, resembling the quiet cultivation of today. The discussions on cinnabar, lead, mercury, and the dragon and tiger in the "Book of Alchemy" are all metaphors for body and mind. The principle that the mind and breath depend on each other is the most direct and obvious: the heart governs the breath, and the breath depends on the heart. When the heart and breath coexist harmoniously, essence, qi, and spirit are abundant, which leads to the avoidance of illness.

    Should one live to a hundred years, death is inevitable, as it has been since ancient times; one merely should not hasten their own demise. Is there really such a notion today of transcending and ascending beyond the world? Some might ask: if nourishment and care are so easy and evident, why are there more who die young than those who live long? The answer is that in matters of diet, daily living, and actions, how can one consistently follow the heart's guidance without making mistakes? When fragrant wine and delicious food are presented, although they may be harmful to the sick, one often cannot resist them. Moreover, when desires stir within, even if one is ill, it is hard to suppress the danger. The intense heart for name and profit and overexertion goes unnoticed. This is the great difference between longevity in ancient and modern times, not due to differences in constitution, but due to the modern neglect of self-care compared to the ancients.[74p]

    曰：吾知精神内守而后饮食起居得其宜，则今之内动外动，皆不足取，而静功收敛精神，不亦得其正乎？曰：若不识尽天年度百岁乃去机括，虽终日闭目，只是一团私意，诤亦动也。若识透天年百岁之有分限节度，则事事循理自然，不贪不躁不妄，斯可以却未病而尽天年矣。盖主于气，则死生念动而昏昧错杂，愈求静而不静；主于理，则人欲消亡而心清神悦，不求静而自静。此俗之所谓静，恐亦异乎古之所谓静也。曰：若然，则吾儒一敬尽之矣。曰：圣学至大，非某能知。[75p]

    He said: I know that by keeping the spirit inwardly guarded, one can manage diet and daily life appropriately. In that case, the movements both inside and outside are not worth seeking. By practicing quietude, one can gather the spirit, which is indeed the correct way. He replied: If one does not recognize the limits of a hundred years and does not let go of worldly attachments, then even if one's eyes are closed all day, it is merely a bundle of personal desires, and the mind is still in motion. However, if one understands the limitations and proper constraints of a hundred years, then everything will naturally follow reason, without greed, impatience, or falsehood, which allows one to avoid illness and live out a full life. If one focuses on energy, thoughts of life and death become mixed up and unclear, leading to a greater desire for stillness that eludes them. If one focuses on reason, human desires dissipate, and the mind becomes clear and joyful, achieving stillness without seeking it. What is commonly referred to as stillness today is likely different from the ancient understanding of stillness. He said: If this is so, then our Confucian scholars are fully devoted to this. He replied: The teachings of the sages are vast and cannot be comprehended by just anyone.[75p]

    但黄帝亦古圣人也，今不信古圣人名言，而信盲人诡异邪说，甚则丧家殒身，见亦谬哉！此吾所以只言保养也。曰保养可勿药乎？曰：避风寒以保其皮肤六腑，则麻黄、桂枝、理中、四逆之剂，不必服矣；节劳逸以保其筋骨五脏，则补中益气劫劳健步之剂。不必服矣。戒色欲以养精，正思虑以养神，则滋阴降火、养荣凝神等汤，又何用哉？薄滋味以养血，寡言语以养气，则四物、四君、十全、三和等汤，又何用哉？要之血由气生，气由神全。神乎？心乎？养心莫善于寡欲，吾闻是语矣。窃有志而未能敢述之，以告我疲癃残疾而不知学者，相与共守乎禁戒，以重此身为万物之本。[76p]

    The Yellow Emperor is also an ancient sage. Now, if one does not believe in the sayings of ancient sages but instead trusts blind and strange theories, it could lead to the ruin of families and loss of life; how misguided! This is why I only speak of preservation of health.

    Is it possible to preserve health without medicine? By avoiding wind and cold to protect the skin and internal organs, there is no need for herbs like Ephedra or Cinnamon; by balancing labor and rest to protect the muscles and bones, there is no need for tonics to replenish energy and strengthen vitality.

    By regulating sexual desires to nurture essence, and adjusting thoughts to cultivate spirit, why would one need decoctions that nourish Yin and reduce fire, or those that promote essence and concentrate the spirit? By eating lightly to nourish blood, and speaking less to conserve vital energy, why would one need the Four Substances, Four Monarchs, Ten Completes, or Three Harmony decoctions?

    In essence, blood is generated by qi, and qi is sustained by spirit. Is it in spirit or heart? To nurture the heart, nothing is better than having few desires; I have heard this saying. I privately harbor intentions but have not dared to express them, to advise those who are weak and unaware of the importance of learning, that together we should adhere to restrictions, valuing this body as the foundation of all things.[76p]

    　　　　医贯 【明　赵献可】

    　　　　　寡欲论

    　　尊生之士，不须服食，不须导引，不须吐纳，能大明生死，几于道矣。生死之门户，不生则不死，上根顿悟无生。其次莫若寡欲，未必长生，亦可却病。反而求之，人之死由于生，人之病由于欲。上工治未病，下工治已病。已病矣，绎其致病之根，由于不谨，急远房帏，绝嗜欲，庶几得之。[77p]

    Discussion on Moderating Desires

    Those who honor life do not need to consume food or practice guiding exercises; they can clearly understand the nature of life and death, becoming almost like the Dao. The gateway to life and death shows that if one does not come into life, there is no death. Those with profound insight realize the state of non-birth.

    Secondly, nothing is better than moderating desires. This may not necessarily lead to immortality, but it can help avoid illness. Conversely, if one pursues excessive desires, death results from life, and illness arises from desires. The skilled practitioner addresses illness before it occurs; the lesser skilled treats what is already present. When illness does arise, trace back to its source, which is due to negligence. Therefore, one should promptly sever excessive desires and habits, so that there is hope for recovery.[77p]

    世人服食以图长生，惑矣！甚者日服补药，以资纵欲，则惑之甚也！　　震本坤体，阳自外来交之，有动乎情欲之象，是以圣人于卦中，凡涉乎震体者，取义尤严，洊雷震，君子以恐惧修省。在复则曰先王以至日闭关，欲其复之静也；在随则曰向晦入晏息，欲其居之安也；在颐则曰慎言语，节饮食，欲其养之正也。明乎此义，而相火不药自伏矣。　　冬至一阳生，夏至一阴生，此二至最为紧要。至者极也，阴处阳生，绝处逢生，自无而有，阳极生阴，从有而无，阳变阴化之不同也。若春分秋分，不过从其中平分之尔。然其尤重者，独在冬至，故易曰先王以至日闭关，闭关二字，须看得广。观《月令》云：是月斋戒掩身，以待阴阳之所定，则不止关市之门矣。
    　　　　医门法律 【清　喻昌】[78p]

    The world seeks longevity through consumption, which is a delusion! Even more so, some take supplements daily to satisfy their desires, which is an even greater folly!

    The Shaking (Zhen) and the Receptive (Kun) represent the dynamic of external engagement with the internal. This manifests in the nature of emotional desires; thus, the sages take the meanings associated with Zhen very seriously in the I Ching. When thunder rumbles, the noble person reflects with fear and self-examination. As for Returning, it is said that the ancient kings closed the gates at the solstice, wanting to restore tranquility. In Following, it is stated that when twilight arrives, one should rest peacefully, desiring stability. In Nourishing, it counsels caution in words and moderation in food, aspiring for rightful sustenance. Understanding this principle, the inner fire will naturally subside without medicinal intervention.

    At winter solstice, one yang is born, and at summer solstice, one yin is born; these two solstices are of utmost importance. The solstice represents the extreme; yin is situated in the birth of yang. This is a transformation from non-existence to existence; yin emerges from the extreme of yang, showing the different transformations of yin and yang. In contrast, the spring and autumn equinoxes merely represent a balanced division thereof. However, the most significant is the winter solstice; hence, the I Ching states that the ancient kings closed the gates at the solstice. The term "closed gates" must be understood broadly. The "Monthly Orders" states that in this month, one should observe fasting and seclusion in anticipation of the fixed interplay of yin and yang, which transcends merely closing the gates of the market.

    Medical Principles and Laws
    [Qing Dynasty, Yu Chang][78p]

    　　　　　调和荣卫

    　　圣人陈阴阳，筋脉和同，骨髓坚固，气血皆从，如是则内外调和，邪不能害，耳目聪明，气立如故。可见调营卫之义，为人身之先务矣。深维其机，觉卫气尤在所先焉。经谓：阳气破散，阴气乃消亡，是卫气者保护营气之金汤也；谓审察卫气为百病母，是卫气者出纳病邪之喉舌也。易云：一阴一阳之谓道，乃其扶阳抑阴，无所不至，仙道亦然。噫嘻！鼻气通于天者也，口气通于地者也，人但知以口之气养营，惟知道者以鼻之气养卫。养营者不免纵口伤生，养卫者服天气而通神明，两者之月异而岁不同也，岂待问哉？　　问：居常调卫之法若何？曰：每至日西，身中阳气之门乃闭，即当加意谨护，勿反开之。经谓暮而收拒，毋扰筋骨，毋见雾露，隐括调卫之义已悉。收者收藏神气于内也，拒者捍邪气于外也，如晨门者昏闭明启，尚何暴客之虞哉？即使逢年之虚，遇月之空，身中之气自固，虚邪亦何能中人耶？[79p]

    Harmony of Nourishing and Defensive Qi

    The sage clarifies yin and yang, harmonizing the meridians and channels, solidifying the bones and marrow; when the qi and blood flow smoothly, both internally and externally are in harmony, and malevolent influences cannot cause harm. The senses are keen, and vital energy remains as it should. Thus, it can be seen that harmonizing the nourishing and defensive qi is of utmost importance for the human body. If one deeply contemplates the mechanism, one will realize that the protective qi is particularly essential.

    The texts state: when yang qi disperses, yin qi will also perish; the defensive qi serves as a golden fortress protecting the nourishing qi. It emphasizes that observing the defensive qi is the mother of all diseases, and defensive qi serves as the throat and tongue through which diseases and evils enter and exit. The Book of Changes states: the way is called one yin and one yang; thus, it supports yang and restrains yin, pervading everything, and the path of immortality is similar.

    Ah! The energy of the nose connects to the heavens, and the energy of the mouth connects to the earth. People usually know to nourish the body with the energy from the mouth, but only the wise understand to nourish the defensive qi with the energy from the nose. Nourishing the nourishing qi often leads to excesses that harm life, while nourishing the defensive qi enables one to align with the celestial forces and connect with the divine, each differing by the lunar and seasonal cycles. There’s no need for further inquiry!

    Question: What is the method for regularly harmonizing the defensive qi?

    Answer: Every evening as the sun sets, the door of yang qi within the body closes; one must pay careful attention to protect it and not allow it to reopen. The texts advise to gather and defend as night falls, avoiding disturbance to the muscles and bones, and not exposing oneself to mist or dew, thus fully understanding the principles of harmonizing the defensive qi. Gathering refers to storing the spirit and energy within, while defending refers to warding off malevolent qi from the outside. Just like the door that closes at dusk and opens at dawn, what fear could there be from disruptive guests? Even during times of emptiness and the phases of the moon, as long as the energy within remains solid, how could external disturbances penetrate?[79p]

    　　　　　谨节五味

    　　问：味过于酸，肝气以津，脾气乃绝，此何解也？曰：此人身消息之所在。王注牵强，不合乎道。夫人天真之气，全在于胃，津液之多寡，即关真气之盛衰，而胃复赖脾以运其津液，一脏一腑，相得益彰，所以胃不至于过湿，脾不至于过燥也。观下文味过于苦，脾气不濡，胃气乃厚，其为脾过燥，胃过湿可知。然终是相连脏腑，嘿相灌渗，所以脾气但言不濡，病反在胃，且未甚也。至以过酸之故，助其曲直，将胃中津液日渐吸引，注之于肝，转觉肝气津润有余矣。[80p]

    Cautiously Moderating the Five Tastes

    Question: If a flavor is overly sour, it draws the liver qi with its fluid, thereby exhausting the spleen qi. What does this mean? Answer: This pertains to the condition of a person's body. Wang's interpretation is forced and does not align with the principle. The innate essence of a person is entirely in the stomach. The abundance or scarcity of bodily fluids directly relates to the vigor of true qi. The stomach relies on the spleen to circulate its fluids; thus, the internal organs complement each other, preventing the stomach from becoming excessively moist and the spleen from becoming overly dry. Observing the following text about the flavor being overly bitter, we can ascertain that the spleen qi is not moistening, and the stomach qi is thick; thus, the spleen is too dry and the stomach too moist. Ultimately, they are interconnected organs that influence one another. Therefore, while the spleen qi is described as lacking moisture, the illness manifests in the stomach and is not severe yet. The excess sourness aids in bending and straightening, gradually drawing the stomach's fluids toward the liver, which in turn makes the liver qi feel enriched and abundant.[80p]

    肝木有余，势必克土，其脾气坐困，不至于绝不已尔。若胃中津液尚充，纵脾气不濡，有濡之者在也，亦安得坐毙哉？　　问：味过于苦，胃气乃厚；味过于辛，精神乃央。注谓厚为强厚，央为久长。岂五味中酸咸甘多所损，苦辛多所益乎？曰：二义原不作此解，王注与经文全相背谬。观于胃气乃厚，绵于脾气不濡，明系脾困不为胃行津液，胃气积而至厚也。胃气一厚，容纳遂少，反以有余成其不足，更难施治。今人守东垣一家之学，遇胃病者，咸用补法，其有愈补愈胀者，正坐此弊。[81p]

    Excessive wood in the liver will inevitably constrain the earth, causing the spleen to be troubled, but it will not be completely exhausted. If the fluids in the stomach are still abundant, even if the spleen's essence is not nourished, there are still those that can be nourished; how can one then sit and await death?

    Question: If the taste is excessively bitter, the stomach's energy will be thick; if the taste is excessively spicy, the spirit will be central. The note refers to thickness as strong and central as enduring. Can it be that among the five flavors, sour, salty, and sweet cause more damage, while bitter and spicy provide more benefit?

    Response: The two meanings were originally not meant for this interpretation; Wang's note is entirely contrary to the text. Observing the stomach's energy as thick, and the spleen's energy as not being nourished, it is clear that the spleen's trouble does not allow for the stomach to transport fluids, leading to a buildup of energy in the stomach which becomes thick. Once the stomach's energy becomes thick, its capacity decreases, and in trying to compensate, it only leads to further deficiencies, making treatment even more difficult.

    Today, people adhere to the teachings of a single school, the Eastern Garden, and when they encounter patients with stomach ailments, they uniformly apply fortifying methods. However, those who apply tonics and find themselves experiencing more bloating are precisely experiencing this issue.[81p]

    如西北之人，喜食生硬面酪，迨至受病，投以牵牛、巴豆，乃始畅适。即香、砂、橘、半，用且不应，况用参、朮之补乎？《内经》有言胃气实则胀，虚则泄，盖可知矣。至精神乃央，上文既云筋脉沮弛，明是筋脉得辛而缓散不收也。况人之精神全贵收藏，不当耗散，宁有辛散既久而不为殃害者耶？曰央，则其为病，且有卒暴之虞矣。相传多食辛，令人夭，岂不然哉！　　问：味过于咸，大骨气劳，从前无解，请一明之！曰：身中消息，有谓心未有不正，肾未有不邪者，以肾为作强之官也。[82p]

    People from the northwest enjoy eating raw and tough wheat cheese, but when they fall ill, they resort to consuming cowherb and croton seeds before they begin to feel better. Spices, sand, oranges, and half of those remedies may not be effective; what then of using ginseng and herbs for nourishment? The "Inner Canon" states that when the stomach qi is full, it leads to distension, and when it is deficient, it causes diarrhea; this is evident. Regarding the spirit, which is central, it has been mentioned above that when tendons and meridians are slack, it indicates that the tendons and meridians relax and do not contract properly. Furthermore, a person’s spirit must be carefully preserved and should not be consumed in excess; can prolonged dispersion of energy not lead to harm? If it is said to be central, then the ailment may have sudden and violent potential. It is commonly believed that consuming too much spice leads to early death; is that not true?

    In response to the question: Excessive salty flavor exhausts the bones and vital energy, and has not been resolved before; please clarify! It is said that within the body, there are indications that the heart is not functioning properly and the kidneys are not performing their duties correctly, as the kidneys are considered the governing organs of strength.[82p]

    有谓肾未有不正，心未有不邪者，以心为情欲之府也。大骨气劳，心肾两有所涉，而实有不尽然者。尝见高僧高道，栖真习定，忽焉气动精倾，乃知味过于咸，大骨气劳之说，不尽关于情欲尔。盖食咸过多，峻补其肾，腰骨高大之所，其气忽积，喜于作劳。气既勃勃内动，则精关勃勃欲开，虽不见可欲而不觉关开莫制矣。经谓强力入房，肾气乃伤，高骨乃坏，此因嗜欲无节者之本病，奈何清修卓炼之士，每于蔬菜间，多食咸藏厚味，以亏道体，无有以《内经》之理一陈其前者！及病已成而食淡斋，长年累月自苦，亦足补偏救敝，然不如当日味无过咸之超矣。因并及之。
    　　　　　和畅性情[83p]

    It is said that the kidney is never without imbalance, and the heart is never without corruption, as the heart is the dwelling place of desires. When the vital essence is overexerted, both the heart and kidneys are affected, yet it is not entirely true. I have seen great monks and enlightened beings, who cultivate truth and meditate, suddenly experience disturbances in their energy and essence, realizing that the taste of excessive salt is detrimental. The notion of overexerting one's vital essence does not solely pertain to desires. Indeed, excessive salt in the diet severely supplements the kidneys, leading to a sudden accumulation of energy that encourages overexertion. Once the energy stirs within, the essence yearns to be released; even if there is nothing visibly desirable, one cannot suppress this urge. The texts state that vigorous encounters harm the kidney qi and damage the bones; this stems from the uncontrolled pursuit of desires. How is it that those who pursue purity and refinement often consume too much salty and rich food among their vegetables, thereby harming their body and failing to align with the principles outlined in the "Inner Canon"? Once illness has taken hold and they adhere to a bland diet for years, it may provide some relief, yet it is far from as effective as moderating salt consumption in the first place. Thus, this matter concerns both aspects.[83p]

    　　饮食入胃，而精气先输脾归肺，上行春夏之令，以滋养周身，乃清气为天者也；升已而输膀胱，行秋冬之令，为传化糟粕，转味而出，乃浊阴为地者也。若夫顺四时之气，起居有时，以避寒暑，饮食有节，及不暴喜怒以颐神志，常欲四时均平而无偏胜则安。不然损伤脾胃，真气下溜，或下泄而久不能升，是有秋冬而无春夏，乃生长之用，陷于陨杀之气，而百病皆起，或久升不降亦病焉。　　本神篇曰：心怵惕思虑则伤神，神伤则恐惧自失。邪气脏腑病形篇曰：忧愁恐惧则伤心。口问篇曰：悲哀忧愁则心动，心动则五脏六腑皆摇。可见心为五脏六腑之大主，而总统魂魄，兼该志意。故忧动于心则肺应，思动于心则脾应，怒动于心则肝应，恐动于心则肾应，此所以五志惟心所使也。设能善养此心，而居处安静，无为惧惧，无为欣欣，婉然从物而不争，与时变化而无我，则志意和，精神定，侮怒不起，魂魄不散，五脏俱宁，邪亦安从奈我何哉！[84p]

    Food enters the stomach, and the essence and qi first flow to the spleen and return to the lungs, rising to follow the commands of spring and summer, nourishing the entire body; this is the pure qi representing heaven. It then ascends to the bladder, following the commands of autumn and winter, processing the waste and transforming flavors outward; this is the turbid yin representing earth. If one aligns with the energies of the four seasons, adapts their daily life accordingly to avoid the cold and heat, regulates diet, and does not indulge in excessive joy or anger to maintain mental clarity, desiring a balanced state throughout the seasons without preference for any, then one remains at peace. Otherwise, damage to the spleen and stomach can occur, with true qi sinking down or leaking out and failing to rise, which signifies there being autumn and winter without spring and summer. This leads to the potential for growth being hindered, caught in the destructive energies of decay, resulting in the emergence of various ailments, and even prolonged ascent without descent can also be a disease.

    The "Spirit Chapter" states: If the heart is anxious and over-thinks, it harms the spirit; if the spirit is harmed, fear ensues and one loses themselves. The "Evil Qi Afflicting Organs" chapter states: Worry and fear harm the heart. The "Inquiry Chapter" states: Sorrow and grief move the heart; when the heart moves, all five organs and six bowels also tremble. It is evident that the heart is the commander of the five organs and six bowels, overseeing the soul and spirit, encompassing desires and intentions. Thus, worry affects the lung, thought affects the spleen, anger affects the liver, and fear affects the kidneys; this is why the five emotions are governed by the heart. If one can nurture this heart well, and dwell in tranquility, without unnecessary fear or exuberance, harmoniously adapting to circumstances without contention, and changing with the times without a sense of self, then one's intentions are in harmony, the spirit is stable, anger does not arise, the soul does not scatter, and the five organs maintain tranquility; thus, evil cannot affect one.[84p]

    　　　　景岳全书 【明　张介宾】

    　　　　　治形论

    　　老子曰：吾所以有大患者，为吾有身。使吾无身，吾有何患？余则曰：吾所以有大乐者，为吾有形；使吾无形，吾有何乐？是可见人之所有者惟吾，吾之所赖者惟形尔。无形则无吾矣，谓非人生之首务哉！但形之为义，其义甚微。如言动视听，非此形乎？俊丑美恶，非此形乎？勇怯愚智，非此形乎？死生安否，非此形乎？人事之交，以形交也；功业之建，以形建也。此形之为义，从可知也。奈人昧养形之道，不以情志伤其府舍之形，则以劳役伤其筋骨之形，内形伤则神气为之消靡，外形伤则肢体为之偏废。甚至肌肉尽削，其形可知；其形既败，其命可知。然则善养生者，可不先养此形以为神明之宅？善治病者，可不先治此形以为兴复之基乎？虽治形之法，非止一端，而形以阴言，实惟精血二字足以尽之。[85p]

    On the Care of the Body

    Laozi said: The reason I have great troubles is because I have a body. If I had no body, what troubles would I have? I would say: The reason I have great joys is because I have form; if I had no form, what joy would I have? It can be seen that what one possesses is merely the self, and what I rely on is merely the body. Without form, there would be no self; is this not the foremost duty of living? However, the significance of form is very subtle. As for movements, sights, and sounds, are they not all manifestations of this form? Beauty and ugliness, are they not reflections of this form? Courage and cowardice, wisdom and foolishness, are they not aspects of this form? Life and death, peace and distress, are they not related to this form? Human interactions are based on form; accomplishments are built upon form. The meaning of this form can be understood accordingly.

    Yet, people are unaware of how to nourish their bodies. If they do not injure their bodily forms through emotions and desires, they instead damage their bodily forms through labor and toil. When the inner form is harmed, the spirit and energy are depleted; when the outer form is hurt, the limbs become impaired. Even to the point where muscles wither away, the form becomes evident; once the form is defeated, the life can be understood. Thus, those who are good at preserving life must first nourish the body as the dwelling of the spirit. Those who are good at treating illnesses must first address the body as the foundation for recovery. Although there are many methods for caring for the body, ultimately, understanding the essence of vital energy and blood is sufficient to encompass it all.[85p]

    所以欲祛外邪，非从精血不能利而达；欲固中气，非从精血不能蓄而强。水中有真气，火中有真液，不从精血，何以使之降升？脾为五脏之根本，肾为五脏之化源，不从精血，何以使之灌溉？然则精血即形也，形即精血也。天一生水，水即形之祖也。故凡欲治病者，必以形体为主；欲治形者，必以精血为先。此实医家之大门路也。使能知此，则变化可以无方，神用自有莫测。然用此之法，无逾药饵，而药饵之最切于此者，不过数味之间。其他如性有偏用者，唯堪佐使而已。亦犹饮食于人，凡可口者孰无资益？求其纯正无损，而最宜于胃气者，则惟谷食类可见矣。或问余以所宜者，果属何物？余则难以显言之。盖善吾言者，必如醴如饴；而不善吾言者，必反借此为射的，以资口吻之基矣。余故不能显言之。姑发明此义，以俟有心者之自悟。古今图书集成医部全录卷三百三十一[86p]

    To dispel external邪, it cannot be achieved without 精血; to strengthen inner气, it cannot be accomplished without 精血. There is true气 in water, and true液 in fire; without 精血, how can one make them rise and fall? The spleen is the foundation of the five organs, and the kidney is the source of their transformation; without 精血, how can one irrigate them? Thus, 精血 is indeed form, and form is indeed 精血. Heaven gives birth to water, which is the ancestor of form. Therefore, anyone wishing to treat illness must prioritize the body; anyone wishing to treat the body must first focus on 精血. This is indeed the great path for doctors. If one can understand this, then transformation can be boundless and divine use can be unfathomable. However, utilizing this method does not exceed medicinal foods, and among these, the most relevant is only a few flavors. Other variations based on individual tendencies are but supplementary aids. Just as in food, who among edible things is without benefit? If one seeks purity and goodness, most suitable for the stomach's气, only grains can be seen. If one asks me what is appropriate, I find it hard to articulate. Those who appreciate my words will naturally find them sweet; those who do not will likely twist them for their own purposes, undermining the essence. Thus, I cannot speak explicitly. I shall clarify this meaning, awaiting those with insight to comprehend it themselves.[86p]

    颐养补益门

    　　　　方

    　　彭祖补阳固蒂长生延寿丹 【《入门》，下同】 　扁鹊用此二十味，浮沉升降，君臣佐使，治劳嗽之疾，无不痊愈。不惟劳疾，凡一年四季，各熏一次，元气坚固，百病不生。及久嗽久喘，吐血寒劳，遗精白浊，阳事不举，下元极弱，精神失常，痰膈等疾；妇人赤白带下，久无生育，子宫极冷，凡用此灸，则百病顿除，益气延年。[87p]

    Nourishing and Replenishing Door

    Formula

    Peng Zu's Vitality-Bolstering Pill for Longevity: This formula contains twenty ingredients used by Bian Que. It regulates rising and sinking, governs the sovereign and officials, and treats diseases like fatigue and cough, with all cases achieving recovery. Not only for fatigue, but also when used once in each of the four seasons, it strengthens the vital energy, preventing a hundred diseases. For chronic cough, shortness of breath, spitting blood due to cold and fatigue, seminal emissions, impotence, extreme weakness of the lower essence, mental instability, phlegm obstruction, and for women with prolonged menstrual disorders or infertility, or a cold uterus, using this moxibustion will eliminate all ailments and enhance vitality, thereby prolonging life.[87p]

    　　人参　附子　胡椒 【各七钱】 　夜明砂　五灵脂 没药　虎骨　蛇骨　龙骨　白附子　朱砂　麝香【各五钱】 　青盐　茴香 【各四钱】 　丁香　雄黄　乳香　木香 【各三钱】　　右为末，另用白面作条，圈于脐上，将前药一料，分为三分，内取一分，先填麝香末五分入脐孔内，乃将余二分药入面圈内，按药令紧，中插数孔，外用槐皮一片，盖于药上，以艾火灸之，无时损易，壮其热气，或自上而下，自下而上，一身热透，患人必倦沉如醉。灸至五六十壮，遍身大汗，上至泥丸宫，下至涌泉穴如此，则骨髓风寒暑湿，五劳七伤，尽皆拔除。苟不汗则病未除，再于三五日后又灸，至汗出为度。学者须用小心。灸至百二十壮，则疾必痊。灸时要慎风寒，戒生冷油腻。保养一月以后，愈加精神健旺。妇人灸脐去麝香，加韶脑一钱。[88p]

    Ginseng, Aconite, Pepper (each 7 qian); Night Bright Sand, Five Spirits Fat, Myrrh, Tiger Bone, Snake Bone, Dragon Bone, White Aconite, Vermilion, Musk (each 5 qian); Blue Salt, Fennel (each 4 qian); Cloves, Realgar, Frankincense, Wood Fragrant (each 3 qian).

    Grind these into a powder. Then, take white flour to make a ring and place it around the navel. Divide the previous medicine into three portions. Take one portion, first fill five qian of musk powder into the navel, then place the remaining two portions of medicine into the flour ring, pressing it down tightly. Puncture several holes, then use a piece of Sophora bark to cover the medicine, and use moxa to cauterize. It should not be hastily done; enhance the heating effect. The moxa should be applied from top to bottom or bottom to top, until the body becomes thoroughly warm, making the patient feel drowsy like being intoxicated.

    Cauterize until reaching fifty or sixty strong applications, making the body sweat profusely, from the brain down to the Yongquan point. By doing so, the wind, cold, heat, and dampness in the bone marrow, along with the five labors and seven injuries, will all be removed. If no sweat occurs, the illness has not yet been cured. Cauterize again after three to five days until sweating reaches the desired amount. Practitioners must be cautious. If cauterization reaches one hundred and twenty strong applications, the illness will surely be healed.

    During cauterization, be careful of wind and cold, and avoid raw, cold, or greasy foods. After a month of care, one's spirit and health will improve further. For women, while cauterizing at the navel, replace the musk with one qian of aromatic brain.[88p]

    　　小接命熏脐秘方　夫人赖精血而成形，其在胞胎，惟有脐带，与母气相通，随母呼吸。十月脱胎，渐长成人，七情六欲，内外交侵，丧失真元，殒躯丧命，良可惜也！余哀闵世人，特传良方，壮固根蒂，保护形躯，熏蒸本源，除却百病，其效如神。每年中秋日，熏蒸一次。　　乳香　没药　猳鼠粪　青盐　续断 【各二钱】 　麝香 【一分】　　右为末，令人食饱仰卧，用荞麦面水和捏一圈，径过寸余，脐大则径二寸，内入药末安脐上。用槐皮一片，复圈药之上，以豆许艾壮灸之。百脉和畅，冷汗如雨。不可令痛，痛则反泄真气。灸至行年岁数而止。无病者连日灸之，有病则三日一次。灸至腹内作声作痛，大便有涎沫等物出为止。只服米汤，兼食白肉黄酒，以助药力。若患风气，有郁热在腠理者，加女子红鉛拌药，则汗易出而疾随愈矣。[89p]

    Secret Recipe for Strengthening the Body

    The essence of life forms through the woman's vital blood, connecting with the maternal energy via the umbilical cord, which follows the mother's breath. After ten months, the baby is born and gradually grows into adulthood, but the seven emotions and six desires invade both internally and externally, leading to the loss of true essence and eventually death—this is truly regrettable!

    I mourn for the people of this world and am sharing this excellent recipe to strengthen the foundation and protect the body. It enhances the original essence and eliminates various diseases, proving effective like magic. It should be performed once every year on the Mid-Autumn Festival.

    Ingredients:

    • Frankincense
    • Myrrh
    • Rat feces
    • Green salt
    • Dipsacus root (each 2 qian)
    • Musk (1 fen)

    Grind these into a powder and have the person lie on their back after a satisfying meal. Mix the powder with buckwheat water to knead into a ring about an inch in diameter and 2 inches if the navel is larger, placing the medicine in the navel. Cover it with a slice of locust tree bark and then circle it again with the medicine, using a small amount of mugwort to apply gentle moxibustion.

    Let the channels flow freely, causing cold sweat to pour off. Be cautious not to induce pain, as it can lead to a loss of true energy. Moxibustion should continue until the person's age is reached. For the healthy, moxibustion can be done for several consecutive days; for the sick, once every three days. Stop when sounds and pain arise in the abdomen, or when foamy stools are passed.

    Only consume rice soup, along with some white meat and yellow wine, to enhance the medicine's potency. If suffering from wind or heat trapped in the skin's pores, add red lead powder to the medicine to promote easy sweating and facilitate recovery.[89p]

    　　接命丹　养丹田，助两肾，添精补髓，返老还童，却病延年。　　大附子 【一枚，切作八片】 　甘草　甘遂 【二两，捶碎】　　右以布包，用烧酒二斤，共浸半日，文武火煮酒干为度。取起附子，去草、遂，加麝香三分，捶千余下，分作二丸，阴干。纳一丸于脐中，七日一换。余丸放黑铅盒内养之。[90p]

    Jie Ming Dan: Nourishes the lower abdomen, supports the kidneys, replenishes essence and marrow, reverses aging and prolongs life.

    Ingredients:

    • Licorice
    • Gansui (two taels, crushed)

    Combine them in a cloth, use two jins of burning liquor to soak for half a day, and boil until the liquor evaporates.     　　卫生方
    　　生地黄 【八斤】 　人参 【三十二两】 　白蜜 【五斤】 　白茯苓 【二十四两】　　永乐中，太医院会议，加天门冬、麦门冬、地骨各八两，进御服食，赐号益寿永贞膏。[93p]

    Sheng Di Huang (Raw Rehmannia): 16 jin, crushed to extract juice
    Ren Shen (Ginseng): 24 liang, finely powdered
    Bai Fu Ling (Poria): 48 liang, finely powdered
    Bai Mi (White Honey): 10 jin, refined to remove dregs

    Mix these ingredients evenly, place in a ceramic jar, seal the jar tightly with five layers of oiled paper and one layer of thick cloth. Suspend the jar in a copper pot filled with water, ensuring the mouth of the jar is above the water level. Cook using mulberry wood fire for three full days and nights. If the water in the pot decreases, add warm water. After the period is completed, remove and seal the jar tightly with wax paper, then immerse it in a well for one full day and night. Afterward, return it to the original decoction and simmer for one full day and night to release the excess moisture, then take it out. Use a small amount first to offer to the deities of heaven and earth, then take one or two spoonfuls mixed with warm wine for consumption, but do not drink wine alone; use clear broth instead, taking two to three doses daily. If it is hot in summer, keep it in a cool place or in ice, or bury it underground, ensuring it is in a secluded area where no animals can be heard and that it is not seen by women or those in mourning. During preparation, avoid any contact with iron utensils. While consuming, avoid foods like scallions, garlic, radishes, and vinegar.

    Elixir of Longevity

    By Danxi

    The poem says:
    Elixir of longevity, it brings peace to the soul.
    Nurturing medicines like chicken brooding eggs,
    Dates must be well-timed.
    Healing must be conducted in a deep room,
    Let no one observe.
    On the night of the Jiazi Gengshen,
    The pills should not see the sky.
    One pill brings an increase of sixty,
    Two pills extend to a hundred and twenty years.
    Taking this medicine is not for ordinary bones,
    Longevity equals that of heaven and earth.
    Keep it deeply secret!
    The source is again renewed.

    Ingredients:
    Fuling (Poria)
    Red Stone Fat
    Sichuan Pepper (lightly fried until sweating),
    Cinnabar (finely ground with water)
    Frankincense (ground together with the wick of a lamp), each one tael, ground separately.

    Use two chicken eggs, remove the clear yellow,
    Place cinnabar and frankincense in each egg,
    Seal with seven layers of paper and store in a green silk bag.
    Have it held on the belly of a strong woman,
    Keeping it warm.
    The cinnabar should be held for thirty-five days,
    The frankincense for forty-nine days.
    Then grind the first three ingredients into a fine powder,
    Mix evenly, using steamed jujube flesh to form pills the size of a mung bean.
    Take thirty pills daily on an empty stomach with warm wine, or in ginseng soup,
    Increasing to forty pills after a month.
    Practice the method in a quiet place on the night of Jiazi Gengshen.
    Avoid letting women, chickens, or dogs see it;
    This is the “Five Elders Rejuvenation Pill.”[94p]

    Banlong Pill [from the "Zhengzhuan"]

    Regular consumption extends life and promotes longevity.

    White Poria, broken old paper (four taels each)
    Deer horn glue, deer horn powder, dodder seed, cedar nuts, cooked Rehmannia (eight taels each).

    Grind the above into fine powder, boil with rice wine to make a paste and form into pills, or dissolve deer horn glue in good wine and mix to make pills, the size of a walnut, taking fifty pills with ginger-salt soup.

    In the past, there was an old man in Shu who sold this medicine in the market, claiming he was three hundred eighty years old. He often sung: "The tailbone doesn't prevent the sea from drying up, the nine-turn elixir is all just talk; only the pearl atop the Banlong can replenish the blood beneath the Jade Hall."

    Those who study this method handed down this recipe. The old man transformed into a white crane and flew away, never to be seen again.[96p]

    　　人参固本丸 【《必用方》】 　夫人心藏血，肾藏精。精血充实，则须发不白，颜貌不衰，延年益寿。药之滋补，无出于生熟二地黄。人徒知服二地黄，而不知服二门冬为引也。盖生地黄能生心血，用麦门冬引入所生之地；熟地黄能补肾精，用天门冬引入所补之地。四味互相为用，又以人参为通心气之主。　　人参 【一两】 　天门冬 【去心，姜汁浸二日，酒浸一日】 　麦门冬 【去心，酒浸二日，泔浸三日】　生干地黄　熟地黄 【并酒浸，各二两】　　右以石磨磨如泥，或烂捣，以杏仁汤化开，漉净滓，又喜净尽如澄小粉之法，撤去上面水，取药粉晒干，乃入人参末，炼蜜和丸梧子大，每取五七十丸，温酒盐汤任下。忌萝卜葱蒜。[97p]

    Ren Shen Gu Ben Wan (Ginseng Solidifying the Root Pill)

    The heart contains blood, and the kidneys store essence. When essence and blood are abundant, the hair does not turn white, and one’s appearance does not decline, promoting longevity. In terms of nourishing medicine, nothing surpasses raw and cooked Rehmannia. People only know to consume the two types of Rehmannia but do not recognize that the two types of Ophiopogon serve as guides. Raw Rehmannia can generate heart blood, while raw Ophiopogon leads to that which is generated; cooked Rehmannia can replenish kidney essence, while Tianmen Dong (the cooked Ophiopogon) directs to that which is replenished. These four ingredients mutually aid each other, with ginseng serving as the principal for harmonizing heart qi.

    Ingredients:

    • Ginseng: 1 tael
    • Tianmen Dong: Remove the core, soak in ginger juice for 2 days, soak in wine for 1 day
    • Mai Men Dong: Remove the core, soak in wine for 2 days, soak in rice wash for 3 days
    • Raw Rehmannia: 2 taels, soaked in wine
    • Cooked Rehmannia: 2 taels, soaked in wine

    Grind the above with a stone mortar until it reaches a paste, or mash it well, dissolve in apricot kernel decoction, filter out the dregs. Ensure it is as fine as powdered sugar. Remove the water from the top, dry the herb powder, then mix in the ginseng powder, knead with honey to form pills the size of a large walnut. Take 50 to 70 pills with warm wine and salted soup as desired. Avoid eating radishes, scallions, and garlic.[97p]

    Deer Antler Frost Pill

    Nourishes the original organs, stabilizes complexion.

    Deer Antler: One set, soaked in water for seven days, scrape off the wrinkled skin, pound into small pieces, store in a silver bottle, and soak in cow’s milk for one day, always keeping the milk above two inches. If the milk decreases, add more until it doesn’t decrease. Seal the bottle mouth tightly with oiled paper.

    In a separate bottle, place one dou of barley, approximately three inches thick. Place the deer antler bottle on top and pack barley tightly around it, leaving the bottle mouth exposed. Steam continuously, adding hot broth whenever the water inside the pot evaporates.

    After one hour, when the antler powder becomes fine like flour, stop steaming and use a fine sieve to separate the milk, then dry the powder.

    　　小刀圭　韩飞霞曰：凡一切虚病，皆可服之。　　小牛犊儿 【未交感者一只，腊月初八日或戊己日杀之，去血燖毛洗净，脏腑不遗，大铜锅煮之，每十斤】　黄芪 【十两】 　人参 【四两】 　茯苓 【六两】 　官桂　良姜 【各五钱】 　陈皮 【三两】 　醇酒 【二斗】 　甘草　蜀椒　食盐 【各二两】　　同煮，水以八分为率，文火煮至如泥，其骨皆捶碎，并滤取稠汁，待冷以瓮盛之，埋于土内，露出瓮面。凡饮食中，皆任意食之，或以酒调服更妙。肥犬及鹿，皆可依此法作之。[105p]

    Xiaodao Gui, Han Feixia said: All虚病 can be treated with this.

    For one unexposed calf (butchered on the 8th day of the twelfth lunar month or on a Wu/Ji day), drain its blood, pluck its hair, clean it thoroughly, ensuring no internal organs are left. Boil it in a large copper pot. For every ten pounds:

    • Huangqi (Astragalus) 10 taels
    • Ren Shen (Ginseng) 4 taels
    • Fuling (Poria) 6 taels
    • Guangui (Cinnamon) and Liangjiang (Galangal) each 5 qian
    • Chenpi (Dried Tangerine Peel) 3 taels
    • Chunjiu (Fine Wine) 2 dou
    • Gancao (Licorice), Shujiao (Sichuan Pepper), and Salt each 2 taels.

    Cook together, using water at an 8:1 ratio, simmering until it becomes as thick as mud. Crush the bones, strain the thick juice, let it cool, and store in an urn buried in the ground, leaving the top exposed. You can consume it freely in any meal or mix it with wine for better effects. This method can also be used for fat dogs and deer.[105p]

    　　八制茯苓丸　治一切虚损，壮筋骨，生心血，乌须发，明目固精；女人滋颜色，暖子宫，调经顺气。　　白茯苓 【二斤半，去皮打碎，如枣大，分为八分：一分用黄芪六两切丝，水六锺，煎三锺，煮汁干为度；一分用肉苁蓉四两酒洗去鳞心，水六锺，煎三锺，煮如前；一分用人参六钱，水五锺，煎三锺，煮如前；一分用秋石四两，水二锺化开令尽，煮如前；一分用枸杞六两，水八锺，煎三锺，煮如前；一分用破故纸五两，水八锺，煎三锺，煮如前；一分用人乳半斤，煮如前；一分用何首乌半斤，黑豆一升，水三升浸，春秋二日、夏一日、冬三日，将浸过首乌黑豆汁煮如前】　　将制过茯苓总入石臼内，捣细筛过，上甑蒸熟，乘热众手为丸。如生子者，每日早晚淡盐汤服四五十丸；如乌须明目固齿者，白汤下。忌烧酒犬肉。修合须用平定成开生气续世黄道吉日。先一日午时，将诸药煎汁，煮茯苓捣末，次日临夜起手，待子时完成，微火烘干，不见风日。忌孝服妇人鸡犬四废并不成日。[111p]

    Eight-Form Poria Pill treats all forms of deficiency and weakness, strengthens the bones and muscles, generates heart blood, darkens hair, clarifies the eyes, and secures essence; for women, it nourishes the complexion, warms the womb, regulates menstruation, and smooths qi.

    White Poria: 2.5 jin, peeled and smashed into pieces the size of jujubes, divided into eight portions: One portion combined with 6 liang of sliced Astragalus, 6 zhòng of water, decocted down to 3 zhòng; one portion with 4 liang of meat corydalis, washed with wine to remove the scales, 6 zhòng of water, decocted as before; one portion with 6 qian of ginseng, 5 zhòng of water, decocted as before; one portion with 4 liang of autumn stone, dissolved in 2 zhòng of water, decocted as before; one portion with 6 liang of goji berries, 8 zhòng of water, decocted as before; one portion with 5 liang of broken rags, 8 zhòng of water, decocted as before; one portion with 0.5 jin of human milk, decocted as before; one portion with 0.5 jin of He Shou Wu, 1 sheng of black beans, soaked in 3 sheng of water for 2 days in spring and autumn, 1 day in summer, 3 days in winter, then the juice from the soaked He Shou Wu and black beans decocted as before.

    Once the Poria is prepared, combine all in a stone mortar, pound finely and sift, steam the mixture until cooked, then while hot, form into pills by hand. For those having children, take 40-50 pills in saltwater every morning and evening; for darkening hair, clarifying the eyes, and strengthening teeth, take with clear soup. Avoid consuming strong liquor and dog meat. Preparation must be conducted on a day deemed auspicious for growth and continuation of life.

    A day before, at noon, decoct all the herbs, cook the Poria, pound it into powder, and the following night, complete the process around midnight, gently dry without exposure to wind or sunlight. Avoid daughters-in-law and children during mourning periods, and no usage on days that are unfit.[111p]

    　　扶桑至宝丹　歌曰：扶桑扶桑高拂云，海东日出气氤氲。沧海变田几亿载，此树遗根今尚存。结子如丹或如漆，绿叶英英翠可扪。真人采窃天地气，留与红霞共吐吞。濯磨入鼎即灵药，芝朮区区未许群。餐松有人已仙去，我今朝夕　此君。叶兮叶兮愿玉汝，绿阴里面有桃源。胡僧曰：蚕食吐丝，织成锦绣；人食生脂，延年除咎。盖嫩桑之叶，性本和平，不冷不热，服之可长生。　　桑叶 【择家园中嫩而存树者，采十数斤，洗以长流水，去蒂暴干为末】 每桑叶净末一斤用黑芝麻四两，阴阳水煎浓汁二碗，去麻存汁，用蜜十二两，炼滴水成珠，将汁入蜜内，和药末捣丸如梧桐子大，每服百丸，早盐汤，晚酒下。久服不已，自跻上寿。起尫羸，济危弱，驻容颜，须白返黑，却疾延年，补髓添精，功效不细。此仙家服食上品，秘密难逢。传匪其人，当有殃咎。戒之。[113p]

    The precious elixir of Fusang

    Song says: Fusang, Fusang, high it brushes the clouds,
    From the East Sea, the sun rises, its breath misty and profound.
    The vast seas have turned to fields over millions of years,
    This tree's roots still remain to this day.
    Its seeds are like cinnabar or like lacquer,
    Green leaves, flourishing and vibrant, are there to be plucked.
    The true person gathers the essence of heaven and earth,
    Leaving it to mingle with the red clouds in exhalation and inhalation.
    Washed and ground, they enter the cauldron as a divine medicine,
    While the chives and herbs are considered trivial and unworthy.
    There are those who have already ascended by consuming the pine,
    But I here, morning and night, seek this gentleman.
    Leaves, oh leaves, I wish for your preciousness,
    Within the green shade is a Peach Blossom Spring.
    The monk from the north says: Silkworms eat and spin silk,
    Humans consume raw fat to prolong life and avert misfortune.
    Indeed, the tender leaves of the mulberry are inherently peaceful,
    Neither hot nor cold, consuming them can lead to longevity.

    For mulberry leaves: [Select young trees in the homestead, gather ten to several pounds, wash in flowing water, remove the stems, and dry rapidly into powder]
    Take one pound of clean mulberry leaf powder, four ounces of black sesame,
    Two bowls of concentrated broth from yin and yang water,
    Remove the sesame and keep the broth,
    Using twelve ounces of honey, refine it until it forms droplets,
    Add the broth into the honey, mix the powdered medicine,
    Form pills about the size of a wutong seed; take one hundred pills,
    In the morning with salty soup, in the evening with wine.
    If taken for long, one naturally ascends to longevity.
    Rising from weakness, aiding the fragile, preserving beauty,
    Turning white back to black, warding off illness, prolonging life,
    Replenishing marrow, enhancing vitality, its efficacy is profound.
    This is the highest-grade food of the immortals,
    A secret rarely encountered.
    If not for the worthy, there shall surely be disaster and misfortune.
    Beware of this.[113p]

    　　药枕方 【《保生要录》】 　治头风目眩。传曰：土厚水深，居之不疾。故人居处随其方所，皆欲土厚水深。土欲坚润而黄，水欲甘美而澄。常居之室，极令周密，勿有细隙，致风气得入。风者天地之气也，能生成万物，亦能损人。初入腠理之间，渐至肌肉之内，内传经脉，达于脏腑，传变尤甚。盛暑不可露卧。自立春后至立秋前，欲东其首；立秋后至立冬前，欲西其首。常枕药枕。其枕药性大热则热气冲上，大冷则冷气伤脑。惟理风平凉者，乃为得宜。[114p]

    Medicine Pillow Recipe [from "Essential Records of Life Preservation"]

    Treats headaches and dizziness. It is said: When the earth is thick and the water is deep, residing there brings no illness. Therefore, people seek places where the earth is thick and the water is deep. The soil should be firm, moist, and yellow; the water should be sweet, pleasant, and clear. The living space should be well-rounded and tightly sealed, with no fine gaps, to prevent wind and air from entering. Wind is the essence of heaven and earth; it can generate all things and also harm people. Initially entering through the pores, it gradually reaches the muscles, internal pathways, and ultimately affects the organs, causing significant changes. During the height of summer, one should not sleep exposed. From the beginning of spring until before the beginning of autumn, one should sleep with the head to the east; from the beginning of autumn until before the beginning of winter, the head should be to the west. Always use a medicinal pillow. If the medicinal properties of the pillow are excessively hot, the heat will rise; if excessively cold, the cold will harm the brain. Only a pillow that harmonizes wind and coolness is appropriate.[114p]

    　　蔓荆子　甘菊花　通草　防风　羚羊角 【屑】 　犀角　石菖蒲 【各八分】 　细辛　白芷　芎藭　槁本【各六钱】 　白朮 【四分】 　黑豆 【五合，拣择净】　　右件药，銼成细末，相拌令均，以生绢囊盛之。欲其气全，次用碧罗袋盛之，如枕样，内药，直令坚实，置在盒子中，其盒形亦如枕，内药囊，令出盒子唇一寸半。晚来欲枕时，揭去盒盖，不枕即盖之，使药气不散。枕之日久，渐低，更入药以实之，或添黑豆，令如初。三五月后药气歇，则换之，勿枕。旬日或一月，耳中微鸣，是药抽风之验。[115p]

    Mān jīng zǐ, sweet chrysanthemum flowers,通草,防风, antelope horn [shavings], rhinoceros horn, stone calamus [eight parts each], xì xīn, báizhǐ, xuāngǔn, dried stems [six qian each], baizhu [four fen], black beans [five he, selected and cleaned].

    The above-mentioned herbs are to be finely powdered, mixed evenly, and placed in a silk pouch. To retain its aroma, use a green ro cloth bag to hold it, shaped like a pillow, filling it with the medicine and packing it tightly. Place it in a box whose shape is also like a pillow, allowing the medicine pouch to extend one and a half inches outside the box lip. When you wish to use it at night, remove the box lid; if not using it, replace the lid to prevent the medicinal aroma from dispersing.

    Over time, as the pillow flattens, add more herbs to fill it, or supplement with black beans to restore its original shape. After three to five months, when the medicinal aroma dissipates, replace it, and do not use it for a time. If after ten days or a month a slight ringing is heard in the ears, it indicates the medicine is taking effect.[115p]

    　　补天大造丸 【《体仁汇编》，下同】 　此方专滋养元气，延年益寿，壮阳光，温坎水，降离火，为天地交泰。若虚劳之人，房室过度，五心烦热，服之神效。养生君子，过四十以来，服之接补，以跻期颐地仙。务必依法制之。　　侧柏叶 【采东嫩枝，隔纸焙干】 　熟地黄 【酒蒸十九次，忌铁，各二两】 　生地黄【酒浸透，忌铁】 　牛膝 【酒洗】 　杜仲 【酥炙断丝】 　天冬　麦冬 【并去心，各一两半】 　陈皮 【去白炒过，七钱半】 　干姜 【炮，二钱】 　白朮【炒】 　五味子 【去梗】 　黄蘗 【酒炒】 　归身 【酒洗】 　小茴 【炒】 　枸杞子 【去梗，各一两】　　右为细末，用紫河车一具，取首男胎者佳，如得壮盛妇亦好。先用新鲜米泔水滤去米滓，将河车浸，轻轻摆开，换洗米泔五次，不动筋膜，只洗净。有草屑轻手取去。[116p]

    Heaven-Sewing Great Pill

    This formula specifically nourishes the original Qi, extends life, strengthens Yang energy, warms the water element, and lowers the fire element, achieving harmony between heaven and earth. It is especially effective for those who are frail, have excessive indulgence in relationships, or experience heat and restlessness in the five hearts. It should be taken by those who are health-conscious and over forty years old, as a supplement to attain longevity like the immortal. It is essential to prepare it according to the prescribed method.

    Ingredients:

    • Cedar leaves (fresh young branches, dried under paper)
    • Cooked rehmannia (steamed in wine for nineteen times, avoid iron, two taels)
    • Raw rehmannia (soaked in wine, avoid iron)
    • Achyranthes (washed in wine)
    • Eucommia (gently roasted, cut into pieces)
    • Asparagus and Ophiopogon (both with hearts removed, one and a half taels each)
    • Aged tangerine peel (remove white part and stir-fry, seven and a half qians)
    • Dried ginger (fired, two qians)
    • Atractylodes (stir-fried)
    • Schisandra (stems removed)
    • Coptis (stir-fried in wine)
    • Rehmannia stems (washed in wine)
    • Fennel (stir-fried)
    • Goji berries (stems removed, one tael each)

    The above should be finely powdered, using one complete purple river car (preferably from a male fetus; a robust female is also good). First, use fresh rice wash to filter out the rice dregs, then soak the river car gently, changing the rice wash five times without disturbing the muscle membranes, only cleaning thoroughly. Remove any grass debris gently.[116p]

    将竹器全盛，长流水中浸一刻，以取生气。以瓦小盆全盛，于木甑内蒸，自卯时蒸起，至申酉时止，用文武火缓缓蒸之，极熟如糊，取出。先倾自然汁在药末内，略和均，河车放石臼内，木杵杵千下，如糊样，通将河车并前药汁末同和均，捣千余杵，众手为丸。此全天元真气，以人补人最妙，世所少知。医用火焙酒煮，及去筋膜，又入龟板，大误，故特出之。凡药末必称净及忌铁器，俱用石臼杵舂，或石磨磨之，不散耗，且远铁。若河车肥大，量加些药末。如干，略用蜜。每日空心米汤下一百丸。有病者，一日服二次。如骨蒸，加地骨皮去木，知母去毛，酒炒牡丹皮去木。如血虚，加当归、地黄倍之。如气虚，加人参、黄芪蜜炙各一两。如肾虚，加覆盆子炒、小茴香炒、巴戟去木、茱萸去核各一两半，此味要净肉。如腰脚疼痛，加苍朮盐水炒、萆薢酒洗、琐阳酒洗酥炙、续断酒洗各一两半。如妇人，去黄蘗加川芎、香附子实、黄芩俱酒炒各一两。[117p]

    To prepare bamboo utensils fully, soak them in flowing water for a moment to imbue them with vitality. Take a small earthenware bowl, fill it completely, and steam it in a wooden steamer starting from the hour of the rabbit until the hours of the monkey and rooster. Use gentle fire for slow steaming until it becomes extremely soft, then take it out. First, pour natural juice into the powdered medicine and mix it slightly. Place the mixture in a stone mortar and pound it a thousand times until it attains a paste-like consistency. Combine the powdered medicinal ingredients and juice thoroughly, and pound it over a thousand times by many hands into pills. This is the true energy of the cosmos, best utilized when one person supplements another—something little known in the world.

    Doctors use fire to roast medicinal wine, to remove tendons and membranes, and also to add tortoise shell—these are great mistakes, hence the particular mention. All powdered medicines must be clean and should avoid iron utensils; use only stone mortars and pestles or stone mills to grind, preventing dispersion and far from iron. If the bamboo is large and fat, slightly increase the amount of powdered medicine; if it's dry, use a little honey. Daily, take one hundred pills on an empty stomach. For someone ill, take two doses a day. If there are bone issues, add earth bone skin and remove its wood, use motherwort without hairs, and wine-fry peony bark to remove its wood. If there is blood deficiency, add double the amount of angelica and rehmannia. If there is qi deficiency, add one tael each of ginseng and astragalus honey-roasted. If there is kidney deficiency, include one and a half taels of fried raspberry, fried fennel, wood-removed morinda, and seed-removed evodia—this requires pure meat flavor. For lower back pain, add one and a half taels of salt-water fried atractylodes, wine-washed rhizoma pubescentis, wine-washed and soft-roasted cynanchum, and wine-washed and soft-roasted fracture herb. For women, remove yellow bristlegrass and add one tael each of chuanxiong, fructus cyperi, and scutellaria, all wine-fried.[117p]

    　　八味地黄丸　滋补之功甚奇，勿轻视之。　　熟地黄 【酒蒸】 　山茱萸 【酒浸去核，取净肉，各八钱】 　丹皮　泽泻 【各二钱小便多，以益智仁代】 　白茯神 【去皮木】 　山药 【蒸，各四钱】 　五味 【去梗】 　麦冬 【去心，各五钱】　　右为细末，炼蜜为丸，每日空心白汤下七十丸，冬天酒下亦宜。[118p]

    The Eight-Flavor Rehmannia Pill has remarkable nourishing properties, so do not underestimate it.

    • Prepared Rehmannia (wine-steamed)

    The immortality pill extends life and promotes longevity.

    Fresh Rehmannia (soaked in wine overnight and then dried), Cooked Rehmannia (washed with wine and dried), Ginseng, Asparagus (soaked in wine for three hours, taken out, dried, and the heart and skin removed), Ophiopogon (prepared similarly to Asparagus, heart removed, three taels each), White Poria (peeled, cut, washed with wine, and dried), Rehmannia Root (washed with wine, five taels each), Fo-Ti (half a pound; fresh should be scraped with a bamboo knife to remove skin and sliced; dried should be soaked in rice wash to soften, skin scraped off and sliced, then placed in a clay pot with one pound of black mutton and three cups of black beans, adding enough water to cover the herbs, steamed for one to two hours, then taken out and dried).

    All are ground into powder, mixed with honey to form pills the size of Wutong seeds. Take three to fifty pills, swallowing them with wine, preferably in the morning. This medicine is extremely beneficial and restorative; after taking it for ten days or a month, you will feel like a different person. The benefits of regular use are difficult to express. Those who obtain this medicine should not easily substitute or share it lightly.

    Deer Antler Powder Pills treat the same benefits.[119p]

    Bai Zi Yang Xin Wan: Nourishes the blood and calms the spirit, enriches yin and strengthens water.

    Ingredients:

    • Bai Zi Ren (Semen Platycladi, steamed and shelled, 4 taels)

    　　却老乌须健阳丹
    　　赤茯苓 【牛乳拌】 　白茯苓 【人乳拌，各浸一宿晒干】 　白首乌 【竹刀去皮打碎】　赤首乌 【制同上，各一斤】 　牛膝 【同何首乌用黑豆五升砂锅内蒸三次】 　枸杞 【酒浸洗晒干】 　当归 【酒浸一宿】 　茯神　菟丝子 【各半斤，酒浸三日晒干】　破故纸 【五两，炒黄】　　右九味，各不犯铁器，另为末，炼蜜为丸如弹子大，日进三丸。早一丸，空心酒下；午后一丸，姜汤下；临睡一丸，盐汤下。初服三日，小便杂色，是去五脏杂病；二七日唇红，口生津液，再不夜起；四七日身体轻健，两乳红润；至一月后，鼻头辛酸，诸风百病皆出；四十九日，目视光明，两手火热，精通，白发反黑，齿落更生，阳事强健，丹田如火，行走如飞，气力倍加。非人不可轻泄，神秘方也。彭用光以炼蜜合作小丸如梧桐子大，每空心酒下五十丸。[122p]

    Here's the translated text:

    "Remove old black hairs, strengthen with Yang elixir.

    Red Poria (mixed with cow's milk)
    White Poria (mixed with human milk, soaked overnight and sun-dried)
    White He Shou Wu (peeled with bamboo knife and crushed)
    Red He Shou Wu (prepared the same way, each one pound)
    Niu Xi (steamed three times in a sand pot with five sheng of black beans, like He Shou Wu)
    Goji berries (soaked in wine, washed, and sun-dried)
    Angelica (soaked in wine for one night)
    Fu Shen, Cuscuta (each half a pound, soaked in wine for three days and sun-dried)
    Broken old paper (five taels, stir-fried until yellow)

    The above nine ingredients should not come into contact with iron tools. Grind them into a powder, refine with honey into pills the size of marbles, and take three pills daily: one in the morning with empty stomach wine, one in the afternoon with ginger soup, and one before sleep with salt water.

    Within three days of initial use, the urine may be discolored; this is a sign of purging the five organs of mixed ailments. By two weeks, lips turn red, saliva increases, and there will be no more midnight awakening. By four weeks, the body feels light and healthy, and the breasts are rosy. After one month, one might experience sourness in the nose; all winds and ailments will emerge. After forty-nine days, eyesight improves, hands feel warm, vitality increases, gray hair turns black, loose teeth regenerate, sexual health strengthens, the lower abdomen feels like fire, movement is swift, and strength doubles.

    This method should not be casually leaked; it is a secret formula. Peng Yongguang used to refine the honey into small pills the size of phoenix tree seeds, taking fifty pills with empty stomach wine."[122p]

    　　四圣不老丹　强筋补益。
    　　明松脂 【一斤，以无灰酒砂锅内桑柴火煮数沸，竹枝搅稠，住火，倾入水内结块，复以酒煮九遍，其脂如玉不苦濇乃止，为细末，十二两】　柏子仁 【去油取霜】 　白茯苓 【末】 　黄菊花 【末，各半斤】　　炼蜜丸如梧子大，每空心，好酒送下七十二丸。须择吉日修合，勿令妇人鸡犬见之。

    Four Sacred Immortal Elixirs do not grow old, strengthen tendons and provide nourishment.

    Ming pine resin (one pound, boiled in a sand pot with ashless wine over mulberry wood until it has boiled several times, stirred with bamboo branches until thick, removed from heat, poured into water to solidify, then boiled again with wine nine times until the resin is like jade, not bitter or acrid, then ground to fine powder, twelve taels)

    　　地髓煎 【《千金方》】
    　　生地黄 【十斤，洗净捣压取汁】 　鹿角胶 【一斤半】 　生姜 【半斤，绞取汁】　蜜 【二斤】 　酒 【四升】　　文武火煮地黄汁数沸，即以酒研紫苏子四两取汁，入煎一二十沸，下胶，胶化，下姜汁蜜，再煎候稠，瓦器盛之，每空心酒化一匕服，大补益。
    　　硫黄杯　此杯配合造化，调理阴阳，夺天地冲和之气，乃水火既济之方，不冷不热，不缓不急，有延年却老之功，脱胎换骨之妙。大能清上实下，升降阴阳，通九窍，杀九虫，除梦泄，悦容颜，解头风，开胸膈，化痰积，明耳目，润肌肤，添精髓，蠲疝坠。又治妇人血海枯寒，赤白带下。　　瓷碗以胡桃擦过，用无砂石硫黄生溶成汁，入白矾少许，则尘垢悉浮，以杖掠去，绵滤过，再入碗溶化，倾入杯内，荡成，杯取出，埋土中一夜，木贼打光用之，欲红入朱砂，欲青则入葡萄，研匀同煮成，每用热酒二杯，清早空心温服，则百病皆除，无出此方也。[124p]

    Diemui Decoction [from "Qianjin Fang"]

    Fresh Rehmannia - 10 catties, washed and crushed to extract juice
    Deer Horn Glue - 1.5 catties
    Fresh Ginger - 0.5 catties, juice extracted
    Honey - 2 catties
    Wine - 4 sheng

    Boil the Rehmannia juice several times over moderate and strong fire. Then, grind 4 taels of perilla seeds with wine to extract the juice, and add it to the decoction for another 10-20 boils. Add the glue, allow it to dissolve, then add ginger juice and honey. Continue boiling until thickened. Serve in a ceramic container, taking one spoonful of this mixture with wine on an empty stomach for great nourishment.

    Sulfur Cup
    This cup aligns with the nature of creation, regulates Yin and Yang, seizes the harmonizing energy of heaven and earth, thus forming a method of balancing water and fire—neither too cold nor too hot, neither slow nor rushed, boasting the ability to prolong life without aging and the miraculous essence of transformation. It powerfully clarifies the upper and solidifies the lower, elevates and lowers Yin and Yang, opens the nine orifices, eliminates nine worms, dispels dream leakage, brightens the complexion, alleviates headaches, opens the chest, resolves phlegm accumulation, sharpens hearing and vision, moisturizes the skin, adds essence and marrow, and alleviates hernias. It also treats women's disorders due to cold blood, including red and white discharges.

    Rub a porcelain bowl with walnuts, use sulfur to create a solution without sand or gravel, and add a small amount of alum to remove all dirt, skimming it away with a stick. Filter through cotton, then dissolve again in the bowl and pour into the cup. Let it rest buried in the earth overnight. Use light from horsetail for application; for a red color, add vermilion, and for blue, add grapes, grinding and mixing thoroughly. Use two cups of hot wine in the early morning on an empty stomach, and all diseases will be dispelled. There is no remedy surpassing this.[124p]

    Zixia Cup

    Sulfur [wrapped in a bag and suspended in a sand pot, boiled with water and purple back floating weeds until it bubbles dozens of times, then dried and ground into powder, ten taels].
    Pearl, amber, frankincense, realgar, vermilion, yangqi stone, red resin, powdered purple brain, white atractylodes, sweet incense, three kinds of nutmeg, wood fragrance, blood resin, myrrh, shaobrain, benzoin [each one qian].
    Musk [seven fen].
    Gold foil [twenty pieces].
    Grind into powder and place in a copper ladle. Melt carefully over a slow fire, using a good sample wine cup wrapped around with powder paper, leaving a hole open. Pour in the sulfur, rotate to mix evenly, and then take it out after cooling. Each morning, serve two or three cups of wine, the effect is the same as above.
